column11: Review Text
Had a great experience . Wonderful day and great fun. A wide variety of items. Good explanation of all the different types of items

Poor service, we waited 20 min at the door for someone to even speak to us about a tour. The ‚Äútour‚Äù we did was tea plucking, she told us what leaves were picked in less than 1 minute and then we plucked a few and left. It was not at all a good experience. Yesterday we went to labookalie and it was a MUCH better experience.

Did both factory and picking tour (1000 rp each). Factory not working Sunday and no pickers because of wind, however an excellent tour ... very good English. Tea tasting was a single cup, but very nice. Picking was fun and got some good photos. Very close to Nuwara Eliya and lovers leap waterfall

column8: Ok if you never visited a tea factory but staff would have finished work so machineries will be silent and place empty .
column11: Having visited a working factory previously , I was disappointed to pay 1000 Rupees each person to wait for a group to form then start the visit. No photos allowed inside the factory.The girl gave good explanation but at times it was difficult to hear what she said. Only the fanning was working when the tea leaves separated debris thus dusts on the floor and staff cleaning machines. Only worth buying Pedro tea as nowhere else sells it ! 95 % for export and only 5 % probably in the shop . It‚Äôs the tea brits drink under different names!

We really enjoyed the tour, the lady gave us lots of information as we went around the factory. You get a cup of tea afterwards, which was enjoyed looking out from their terrace across the tea estate, which was stunning. Recommended.

column8: Go early to see the factory working
column11: We were recommended to visit early as the tea processing happens overnight. The visitor centre opens at 8 am. We had an excellent tour at 8.30am with Kaushi. The cutting machines and sorting machines were still working. Sadly no photos are allowed inside the factory which is such a shame. The tour took about 20 mins and was really informative. Then we were given a cup of tea on the balcony overlooking the plantation. We also paid another 1000 rupees for the plucking tour. This was very disappointing and not worth the money. Kaushi gave us bags to wear and took us out to the tea plantation. She explained how the pluckers work, selecting one bud and two leaves and then said we had 20 minutes to pick tea ourselves. We decided against that, instead walking to photograph some of the tea pluckers. Of course they wanted to be reimbursed for having their photos taken, so have plenty of small notes and wear sturdy shoes!

column8: Great tour of a Tea Factory
column11: Great factory to visit. Set in a very scenic location. The lady giving the tour was excellent - she answered all my questions and provided us with plenty of information. Highly recommended

column8: Not worth the money at all
column11: Extremely Disappointed ‚Äì Not Worth the Money! Pedro Tea Factory is an absolute rip-off! They charge 1000 rupees just for a basic factory visit ‚Äì no complimentary tea, no plantation walk, nothing extra. That price is outrageous considering other tea factories in the area offer much better service and a more immersive experience for half the price or even free. On top of that, the staff were shockingly rude and unwelcoming. They clearly don‚Äôt care about tourists or customer service. It felt like we were an inconvenience to them. There are plenty of other tea factories in Nuwara Eliya that are far more worth your time and money. Don‚Äôt waste either of those at Pedro. Highly disappointing.

column8: Not worth the time and money
column11: Dreadful tour. Charged 1k rupees to be show around the factory by someone that couldn‚Äôt be bothered. The staff were less than impressed that we had chosen their tour above all others. Don‚Äôt waste your time, here are many tours to go on and I wish we had picked a different one.
Over priced and completely commercial. Moreover there is nothing to see in the factory or the lounge. Over hyped. Arrogant staff.

The factory tour is actually much shorter than I expected. I had difficulty hearing what the tour guide was saying as a lot of background noise . Given a cup of tea to sample at end of tour. Teas in the shop are very expensive. Please note lots of steps up and down during the factory tour  - not the easiest.

We had an excellent walk up to this place from our hotel at the quiet end of the lake. It's a peaceful walk (more interesting than tuktuk) We didn't do the tea factory tour but enjoyed a free cuppa overlooking the beautiful tea gardens and bought tea that was surprisingly well priced compared to the previous tea factory we visited. We then took a gorgeous walk up to lovers leap waterfall. Highly recommended. NB get the bus back into town from here,it's cheap as chips and do walk up to the waterfall the views are stunning

This wasn't a planned visit...on our way back from Lover's Leap our tuk driver suggested a visit to take part in their factory tour.... even though we've done this a couple of times before we thought why not and proceeded.... And it turned out be the best tea factory tour we've had so far! It was a precise and concise tour of 20 mts where they take you through each division of the factory while explaining the tea making process from end to end. And it was also the most informative of all the tea factory tours we've had so far. The lady who did the tour did an excellent job. She was very knowledgeable and answered many questions. We went there around 10.30 am and immediately joined a tour that was just about to start. After the tour you get a nice cup of tea. (I think there are tours every half an hour.) If you arrive while a tour is ongoing they will serve you tea first which you can enjoy in their tea lounge while enjoying the lovely view. We paid LKR 500 each and I think it was the same for locals and foreigners. No photos or videos are allowed inside the factory. [If I am nitpicking, the aprons they provide visitors to wear during the tour can do with a makeover.] We Also learnt that the name of the Estate is pronounced as "Peedro" (not "Pedro")  same as how the British colonists called "Piduruthalaga" the highest mountained "Mount Pedro", pronounced as "Mount Peedro". The factory is quite close to Nuwara Eliya town. Road conditions are good. It's on the side of the Udupussellawa road and there is ample parking inside the property. They also have a collection of single estate tea for sale. If you are interested in touring a tea factory and learning about the tea making process I would highly recommend this tour.

We had a four-person lead with another couple. The employee guided us in the fast-track max. 15 minutes through the factory. She spoke very good English, but she rattled down the information as if memorized, so you could hardly follow. In the end, there was no tea tasting, the real reason we had visited the factory in the first place. On request, it was said that there were currently no more samples. Milk was also no longer in stock. Too bad!

Entrance costs 1,000 rupees per person, the tour is very short, about 15 minutes, and you can only see the machines themselves but you can't see the creature itself because it only happens at night. There's a feeling that the tour was done in an area only for tours and that they don't show the factory itself. The machines they look very dusty and outdated, really feel like a fake representative.

We loved the explanation as part of the tea factory visit, they charged us 500LKR per person for the tour however we weren‚Äôt told the factory is under renovation. There was construction and civil work happening inside the factory and we couldn‚Äôt see the entire process. When I made the suggestion to the front desk staff  that they could have told us about the work happening inside, they said yes reluctantly! Cup of tea served after the tour was delicious.

Definitely not worth the detour. Totally selfless guide. Quick visit. Very little explanation. We waited 1/2 hour before being picked up. She blocked us at the entrance on the way back... plus the tea is horribly expensive.

We were staying in Nuwara Eliya for a couple of days and wanted to visit a tea plantation and this was recommended by the hotel (Grand). We took a Tuk-tuk from the hotel and the driver waited for us while we did the tour (approx 45 minutes in total including time to drink and buy tea). Very informative tour with a chance to see production from start to end with a good tour guide who was keen to answer questions. Great selection of tea to buy with a good explanation of what you are buying. We brought lots back. This felt like a  much more local experience than the commercial plantation that we stopped at on our way out of Nuwara. So would definitely recommend this - local, less expensive and felt a bit more real.
Nice place, pleasant and very professional guidance, kind. Lovely. Indulging in a cup of tea üçµ, relatively expensive but special shop, worth a visit, spectacular view

We really do not recommend this plan for tourists. No welcome, they left us waiting without any information for 1/2 hour. Not enough staff to receive customers. The visit to the factory is uninteresting, not sufficiently supported, sloppy. The guide repeats the same information over and over again without answering the questions asked. Don't waste your time, look elsewhere, another area.

Great experience. 500LKR/pax for an interesting tour around the tea factory (photos prohibited) and a complimentary cup of tea. 1000LKR/pax to have a practical demo of tea picking, and 15/20 minutes to try it out yourself. 1100LKR/pax for tea tasting. Overall, a cheap and fun afternoon out!

We did a short tour here. I enjoyed seeing the old factory and old machines that are all still in use. You can see some old photos as well  of important people who have visited over the years. A good explanation of how tea is made. A nice cuppa at the end as well.

The young lady guide was pleasant but the factory tour showed how many manual processes are yet to be automated. The newest machines seemed to be from 1986. As the factory operates between midnight and 0600 hours when the area is at its coolest, all we could watch was a couple of workers separating picked tea leaves as well as others carrying heavy bundles between sites. Some visitors went down a hill to see how an employee picks the leaves.  It needs skill, and constant avoidance of thorns.  Not a job I'd have ever enjoyed, especially given the midday heat. The gift shop was the focus of the estate.  Along with a cup of tea it concluded the experience.

We were staying local to Pedro Tea Estate and visited one afternoon. Firstly we were offered free roaming of the tea plantation and walked down to near the lake, then had a complimentary tea & a tour. Hashini was very knowledgeable & explained the process very well. Photos were not allowed inside however the outside was very scenic. At the end, you could buy some of the tea made, which I assume is where revenue comes in. Overall I‚Äôd definitely recommend this experience!

For us, however, it was a beautiful experience: the plantation tries to respect ethics and sustainability criteria and for this reason it differs from the others. We visited the factory with the original 19th century machinery still working and the explanation was concise but exhaustive. At the end they offered us an excellent cup of tea, accompanied by a freshly fried spicy 'rollo': delicious.

The factory tour was very quick and it was difficult to hear what the guide was saying. Explanations (what we heard) were exceptionally brief and we were not allowed to really look at the process or take photographs.

Unlike the Damro plantation you have to pay for a factory tour - which wasn‚Äôt actually productive at the time of our visit ,  just running the sizing side of the process.  We waited an age in the foyer for any instructions on where and when the tour would start. The lady who finally showed up led us off in too large a group size - such that only those directly next to her could hear her.

At first glance, the place looks nice except that the factory tour costs 500 RPS, If you want to see the tea fields and pick a little you will need to add 1000 rps Then if you want to taste a tea even a little to know what you are buying you will have to add 1100 rps All done in a clearly expeditious manner, Visit to the factory (20 mins), For the collection, we give you a bag, we tell you: you go there, you pick it up, you have 20 minutes and I will come back to pick you up! The store... No possibility of buying an individual box, there are only packs of 6 for the price of 6500 rps... No authenticity... Disappointed!!!
They take you on a short tour of their tea factory and plantation. You have to pay a fee for the tour. You will to taste the tea grown there

You can visit wonderful tea gardens and taste tea. There are short tours in the factory where you can see the tea production step by step, and there is a free tea tasting at the end of the tour. There is also a sales office where you can buy gift tea.
Very disappointing visit lasting 10 minutes for a cost of 500 rupees. We visited with a couple who had been to other much nicer free tea factories. Incomplete visit

We bought 2 tickets for factory visit and the tea collection, entire tour was super unorganized, lady who has provided the factory tour did the tour with unprofessional attitude as if she was forced to give us a tour; no communication whatsoever when we reached back to the main entrance. Then she gave us the baskets and told us to walk in the garden‚Ä¶ then the toilets (female) were disgustingly dirty; flush was not working either. I would not do it or recommend it to any of my friends.

Don‚Äôt go on Saturday. There‚Äôs nobody working. The tour is done in 10 minutes (does not include the fields, just the factory) and the price is not worthy (at least at the weekend). I have visited other tea factories for free and you just pay for what you buy. Here we were charged 500LKR per person for practically nothing. A waste of money and time during the weekend.

The visit was hasty, the explanation in English difficult to understand from a rather rude companion. It is also the only tea factory and plantation where an entrance fee of 500 rupees is required. At the end you can make purchases in the shop. If you want to visit a plantation there are better solutions in the area, much larger and free.

As we already did a tea factory tour at another site on the way to Nuwara Eliya, we decided to only do the Tea plucking for 2k Rupees on the Pedro Estate. We actually hoped for some explanation or that they would weigh the leaves we picked afterwards, but it was really just handing out the cappy-held baskets (which smelled like old sweat btw) and nothing more. The field next to the site is nice to take some pictures, but we really had hoped for more than just this.

Pedro Tea Factory is a reasonably small facility, but located on their Lovers Leap tea estate, just minutes from Nuwara Eliya township, so reasonably easy to visit. The factory tour takes about 20 minutes and costs 500 LKR per person.  Most of the machinery in the factory was sitting idle, but our guide said that the processing was done at night due to the different humidity and drying qualities.  A number of reviewers have said how informative their tour was, but that wasn't the case with ours. Our tour guide was quite unengaged. The tour felt rushed, she parroted a few facts quickly and quietly in each room of the factory, and was very difficult to hear or understand. I don't think anyone on our tour came away with much more knowledge on tea production than they went in with. You weren't permitted to take photos in rooms with grading equipment. The reception area of the tours was modern, with a balcony overlooking a small tea planting. There were a few women plucking leaves below the balcony, but they appeared to be doing it primarily as a photo opportunity for tour participants. There is also a walking track to Lovers Leap Waterfall from the factory site.
The visit at Pedro Estate was so nice. We could take a walk through the beautiful garden, taste delicious black tea and got a very interesting tour through the factory.

We had a four here with tea tasting at the end. It‚Äôs an eye opener to what the ladies experience during their working hours in the factory especially in the drying room which is extremely hot! Tour guide was brilliant and very informative. Tea tasted so good had to buy some!

This tour is quite dull. It only took about 10 minutes, and no photos are allowed. If it was a free tour, it would be fine, but I'm not sure it's worth paying for. We saw the tea factory at the Heritance Tea Factory hotel- it was free, and much better.

Nice tea estate and one of the oldest. Tour of the factory is not free. There are other 2 tea factories in Nuwara Eliya , which I believe are better in terms of service. Staff seemed to be least interested in selling the products, which is unusual for Sri Lanka.

We intended to go on a factory tour, but they told us the factory wasn‚Äôt running at the moment. We decided to do a tea tasting instead. 6 cups of tea were put in front of us without any explanation.. I then asked someone for an explanation, she just told me which cup was which tea, no further explanation.

This is where we purchase our tea from every time we visit Nuwara Eliya. We have visited Pedro tea factory over 5 times now. This was our 7 month old's first time though. The tea is superb and the view of the tea plantations from the viewing deck is a nice experience. We did experience the factory tour once which was very informative. Highly recommended for a nice experience if you enjoy Ceylon Tea.

Impressive to see all the tea plantations in Nuwara eliya, which are very big. We had a very good tour guide who showed us the factory and explained the process of making tea very clear. Also very impressive to see under which circumstances the employees live.
Lovely old tea factory in the hills.  we were given a tour of the factory and shown  how the leaves are processed. At the end we got to taste 2 kinds of tea. The tea is brewed for exactly 5 minutes.

I only ever leave reviews when things are really good, or very bad and this was very VERY BAD. We had wanted to do the factory tour and were told on our arrival that we weren‚Äôt able to because the factory wasn‚Äôt open for visitors that day (oddly). We were told that the only two activities we could do where the two (more expensive at 1100 Rs pp) ‚Äúexperiences‚Äù of Tea tasting or Tea picking; we opted for the tea tasting. We said we understood that the factory was closed for tours but asked if it would be possible to pop our heads round to see the inside of the factory? The woman said yes. So we sat down for our tea tasting, and after 10 minutes a tray of tea was plonked in front of us, a different woman pointed and said some teas were strong and others weren‚Äôt, and then departed(!) There was no explanation about the variations of tea on the tray, how they are grown, or what they were even! Nothing. Nada. We were just left to our tray of random teas. It was an absolute joke. We tried to find someone to ask questions but got minimal information and no actual explanation on the process. We then said asked if we could have a quick look round the door at the factory, and the woman in charge said ‚Äúyes that‚Äôs fine, that‚Äôll be Rs.350 each‚Äù i.e. the cost of the tour which we had initially asked for and were told that we couldn‚Äôt do!! I queried why we were told merely 15 minutes earlier that we couldn‚Äôt do the tour of the tea factory, at which point the woman basically lied to us and claimed she had included it as an option!! She was basically scoffing at us as she spoke implying that all 3 of us had misunderstood. The Sri Lankan driver who had driven us there and was waiting and had heard the whole thing was as shocked as we were at the audacity of this woman. (And won‚Äôt be recommending anyone go there again). This is an absolute waste of time please avoid and don‚Äôt make the same mistake we did by going to this shambles of a factory.

We were supposed to go to Damro but went here instead as land slides had blocked the road. A very average factory tour: the attendant walked us through the entire tea-manufacturing process in their factory. Nothing spectacular, just an average tour. They didn't have a lot of varieties of tea for sale either.

We live in USA and was visiting family in Sri Lanka. Our whole family took a tour of the factory. Then they served us tea, which tasted very good. We bought 5Kgs of tea from them, since they ensured that it would taste the same as the ones that they served. After we came back to USA, we tried the tea. All the tea tasted like rotten moldy grass with a hint of plastic. It was horrible. We are so disappointed that an actual tea factory sold us crappy, terrible tea.
Visit this place for a nice cup of tea and to buy tea leaves. Also they do factory tours where the kids can learn the routine and tasks of a tea factory.

We were really disappointed with our visit to Pedro Tea Factory. Firstly when we arrived noone greeted us, the staff all ignored us and it was really unclear where we were supposed to go. We figured out we had to buy tickets and were then told to wait 10 minutes until the tour started. We waited 30 minutes without any further communication about the tour. Another staff member did give us a cup of tea but with no explanation, we weren't really sure if it was actually supposed to be for us. We chose a table to sit at, but they were all very dirty with bits of food and flies and dishes unclear from previous guests. Finally our tour guide came to get us for our tour, she was very unenthusiastic and came across as in a hurry and disinterested. During the tour, our guide was very rude to other guests in our group. The guide's accent was a bit hard to understand at the best of times (not her fault as English is her second language), but she told two members of our tour group (who English was also not their first language for) that taking photos was not allowed. They clearly did not hear her/understand what was being said, and instead of gently making sure they understood, she yelled at them "do you even speak English?!". After the tour was finished she just walked off without saying goodbye or thanks or anything. Such a bad experience from start to finish! The previous day we did a tour at Damro and it was amazing! I'd definitely recommend avoiding Pedro and going to Damro instead.

Nuwara Eliya is a hill-station and we were not going to leave without seeing at least a couple of tea gardens and tea factories. Two of the most famous tea gardens in this town are the Pedro Tea Factory and Damro Labookellie Tea Factory. We drove to the Pedro Tea Factory. This is NOT a working factory and therefore we decided to skip the factory tour and instead walked part of the tea garden.

Comparatively a small factory built in 1885, yet an interesting tour. Located just 3.5 km from the Nuwaraeliya city center makes its one of the few factories closer to the town. As soon as you enter the premises , it‚Äôs start smelling tea. Tickets for the tour is available at the counter in  ‚ÄúLover‚Äôs Leap‚Äù Ethical tea boutique. Boutique is located right opposite the car park down  towards the tea estate. Tickets comes with a free cup of tea which is free to enjoy before or after the tour. Boutique's clean and well maintained ambiance was so relaxing and offer a perfect view of the greeny tea estate. There was a fair collection of Ceylon tea to be purchased. However, lesser verities. Didn‚Äôt see a large collection of flavoured or infused teas. Reason may be this place only sells the pure tea straight from their factory without any infusions or additions. Only pure tea as it is. ‚ÄúLover‚Äôs Leap‚Äù, the Boutique got this name in reference to a nearby waterfall with the same name. Supposedly the name was given after an ancient prince and his lover leapt into death from the particular waterfall. Tour was fairly short since the factory is small (just about 10-15 minutes). But worth the experience. What I loved most is purchasing different kinds of Ceylon tea. If your itinerary is too tight and does not permits much time to travel a factory too far from city or long tea tour, this is an ideal place.

The tour took 15mins at most including the walk from the boutique to the factory and back. We were provided only very basic information about the manufacturing process,none about tea fields, tea bushes or plucking. We didn't have an opportunity to ask questions,as the guide simply told us (at what seemed like a random point of the tour) to take a seat in order enjoy a cup of tea, without saying goodbye or in any other way suggesting that the tour had come to an end. Expecting her to at least tell us what kind of tea we would be served (to this moment we do not know) or asking us whether we had any questions was apparently too much to ask. We would have at least partially understood this kind of attitude had the factory been busy,but we only came across three other guests in the facilities who had already been taken care of. Definitely not worth 250 rupees. We ended up finding out a lot more about tea production from blogs written by tourists who visited other factories,which I find very sad. Honestly I fail to understand the added value of taking the tour. You can simply stroll through the countless tea fields above the factory (with better views) and later enjoy a nice cup of tea at a restaurant while reading about tea production on wikipedia. I sure hope that the tours at other factories are more worthwhile.

This factory is located in the middle of a beautiful tea estate. It feels weird when we are there. The tea factory, which was created by the British, is still running. If you are going to Nuwara Eliya, don't forget to visit this place.
best tea factory.  very nice. good explain staff. very taste tea in factory outlet.  best luck. I'm japan

Excursions to the factory goes every half an hour. (Till 16.30, as I remember) If you want to see working machines, you need to come in early mornings (may be not all days) But it‚Äôs not necessary to see  exactly working process. It‚Äôs interesting anyway. Guides speaks English, so all information is understandable. You could see old machines and know many interesting facts about tea manufacture. The smell of tea is amazing. And also you could walk among tea trees on tea plantations behind the factory. It‚Äôs very beautiful. You could see the process of picking tea leaves into special baskets. Working women could show you tea leaves and you could taste it. So also they suggest you to take a photo with them, but they also wants you to pay for photos. And it‚Äôs strange. Also you could but very good tea in a factory shop. In the shop you could ask about process of brewing tea. It‚Äôs a good gift.
Their prime intention is to make you purchase their products. the climate is very soothing. can visit.

Overall the place is very nice. However, we did not receive a fair treatment. After purchasing the ticket they told us that the factory was not working that day and therefore the machines were off... The girl who guided us through the tour was just repeating phrases that she clearly memorized few days before... also the level of English was quite poor. On the other hand, you get the chance to walk around the plantation and to drink a nice cup of tea at the end.

Went here because of youtube recommendation. We visited couple of tea factories in Sri Lanka, but we liked this one the least. It was the only one factory, where we had to pay for entrance and the only one where the staff absolutely did not cared about us. The visit of the machines in factory was quite fast. I don't mind paying for attractions like this and to support local businesses at all, but in all other free factories the experience was better. We even payed extra for tea tasting, but that consisted only of bringing 6 different teas in front of us without any further explanation about them or even telling which one is which. Therefore we did not buy any presents here and considered the visit as a waste of time. Don't always believe youtubers :(

We visited Pedro Factory on Monday but there was nothing happening.  We were told that the factory does not function on Mondays - very strange.  According to our driver/tour guide, each time he visited this factory the equipment was not functioning.

Nice setting especially combined with a walk to Lover‚Äôs Leap Waterfall Factory tour is 250rp - we went on a Sunday and not much was happening so better to try another day.  It was nice walking around the tea plantation.  Staff were friendly and the cup of tea great.

Went to this factory to see the tea process.  As others have said, nothing working on the day.  We got a guide who was very quietly spoken and difficult to hear.  She told me off for having my camera open and when I asked her a question she told me to ask one of the tourists and flounced off in a huff, bringing our tour to an end.  Nice location but staffer was rude.  She was the only rude Sri Lankan we came across in our 1 month holiday, so it really left an impression (not a good one).

This tea factory offers a tour of key production processes.  It is unfortunate that the factory is not actually operational during the daytime.  Explanations were clear and concise.  Refreshment is available and a small shop selling their products
Very hospitable staff, breathtaking views whilst you away the tour sipping fresh tea. They even have a little shop where you can buy some tea
many varieties of tea and The tour was wonderful  The guide was explained everything nicely also price is cheap

We had a visit to the Pedro tea factory , the factory is an excellent example of the processing required to convert the picked tea to the delicious end product. The tour is not long but showed the processes they went through. It was fascinating to see the old processing equipment still in use. Though it was disappointing the factory was not in use during our visit as it was a Monday and no fresh tea was being processed.
This tour gives a good insight to how tea is manufactured and is located in a very picturesque setting. The tour is not too long at 30 minutes and only costs R250 pp which we felt was reasonable.
The tour at the factory was kinda short but also cheap. And it was so nice to stroll on the tea plantations after the tour. Also cup of tea was offered.

We got a fine tour through the factory. Be aware that they work during night, so most machines are turned off. Got a nice cup of tea after the tour. The tea they sell is quite overpriced so buy elsewhere.

A three wheeler from Nuwara Eliya centre to the Pedro costs 350-400 rupees. The estate is in a picturesque setting and the tour is very reasonably priced at 250 rupees per person. Pedro cares about its staff and the environment - both important factors when considering which plantation to visit. The workers were off and the cleaners were in when we went round, that was fine as they warned us. The best part was talking to the tea pluckers at the end. And the cup of orange pekoe!

We arrived at Pedro Tea Factory via tuk tuk (we paid 500rupees from the city centre, negotiating it from an original 1000 rupee 'tourist rate') and were ushered to join a tour (250 rupees each for foreigners). What i couldn't really find information on, was if the tour timings were adhoc or at certain times in the day. When we arrived, everything seemed more adhoc - and it appears the tours run frequently enough  and there aren't any minimum tour sizes for them to start (our tour group was 4, whereas others were 10+ people).... so arrive when you can and I'm sure the waiting time will be limited. Tour guide was friendly enough, communication was good and she was happy to take questions. You do get a free tea at the end of the tour and then we actually spent sometime just sitting and enjoying the view. There are plenty of tuk tuks waiting to take you home just outside of the gates or as many did to us on our walk down, offered to take us home.

This was interesting if you‚Äôve never been to a tea factory before, but on the day we visited the machines were not working which was a little disappointing. Also the guide who was very pleasant spoke in a quiet voice and was incomprehensible for most of the people in our group.  Also we didn‚Äôt see the actual T plucking and all exactly how this was done which was disappointing and could‚Äôve been explained in more detail. However the building and machinery was interesting to look at.

We went to this factory because it has been awarded with multiple certificates for treating their worker ethically. They tour of the factory was only 250 rs. The tour is rather quick and the machines are not operating (they work at night) which for us was okay. It gave us a good enough idea about the production of the tea. Afterwards you get a tea and also can buy tea if you want to. I really liked to browse the little shop, since there was no hassle and nobody was pushing us to buy something. We could even try different teas and take our time to make a decision which tea we want in the end.

All tea factories in Sri Lanka is same, we went to tea factory in Lipton seat, this one is also similar to that one, but the free tea they give after tour, is amazing ;) you have to pay 250 rupee per person...

We think it is just another Tea Factory. I too thought the same. I have being to many tea factories in my life. But the Pedro tea factory itself is different. The building structure is unique and as explained by my Friend Nadun Madushan, the Assistant Manager, it is built in the style of an Chocolate Factory. In order to maintain a high standard of quality, tea manufacturing is done only during the night when the weather is colder. Therefore, the action is very low during the day time. But don't be worried there are plenty of staff who are well trained to take you on a guided tour on how tea is manufactured. Due to security reasons the management doesn't allow anyone to take photographs inside the premises. Their tea boutique is also a very cozy place to visit and have a nice cup of tea and purchase whatever the flavor you wish to have. And over looking the tea boutique is the lovely scenery of the tea estate. Time spent here is very relaxing and memorable. This place is a must visit to anyone who visits the beautiful Nuwaraeliya.

We went on a Sunday so no picking or processing happening but lovely staff showed us around .Certainly puts a different perspective on a simple cup of tea ! Such hard physical work for the ladies picking . Great tea samples after the tour.

Our group visited the Perdro Tea Plantation & factory as part of our tour of the Hill country. They produce Lovers Leap ethical tea. We were shown around the factory by a local plantation worker who explained the tea production process & showed us the various steps from picking to drying & quality control. She was very interesting in describing a very labour intensive process. We also saw tea pickers & had a cuppa in the factory tea shop. Very enjoyable & informative.

The price of the tour is not much, but the commentary was pretty uninspiring. The only two sections of the factory working at the time was the sorting of the finished tea into its various grades from the top grade orange pekoe to the tea dust.  We did see the first process but I didn't hear the name where the leaves are initially dumped in big bays to be dried with wood fire heat to remove enough moisture from the leaves to make them rubbery and then allow the rolling process. But there was no machine on to show the rolling, the fermentation, or the cutting etc. After seeing the sorting, we saw the packaged product ready for auction, then  it was back to the shop for a cup of their tea but no explanation of what we were drinking etc. So a pretty short and basic tour of the factory with a commentary that hard to hear at the best of times, but was inaudible when the sorting machine was on. We didn't see any tea pickers.  I think by the afternoon they were all clocking off. The tea fields were nice to look at.  The tea in the cafe was nice.

We went to this on our way to Heritance Tea Factory. Unfortunately it was a Sunday so the factory wasn‚Äôt working but we saw a tea factory and got a good explanation of its working. Worth the hour stop. They don‚Äôt allow photos. No idea why not.
Excellent tour followed by a lovely cup of Pekoe. No better place to find out what makes a good cuppa and - see photos- a bit of a looker!

Interesting tour but two groups merged to one as they were short staffed so over 35 people walking around the factory together was not ideal. Some of the group were elderly and the many steps and metal staircases were a bit challenging which also slowed down the tour. Free cup of tea at the end and the views from the cafe are fabulous.
A good tea factory that can feel a good taste of tea with a very good view and also a place with nice waterfall view called Loverslip.

Went here to have a look at the lounge .. it‚Äôs beautiful surrounded and overlooking the tea estate !! A cup of tea here just to sit and watch the view is great .. went venturing out in the tea estate itself plucking tea leaves !! The tea cake wasn‚Äôt the most delicious ones I‚Äôve had but it was okie !!

Tea factory with factory tour and shop plus nice views. We had a brief group tour which cost 250LKR each for approx 30min tour. The tour guide was arguing with workers for a long period of time and I got the sense we were not welcome to watch the workers load up tea. That said we had a rudimentary tour of the factory and I left with more knowledge about tea than I came with. At the end we all had a complimentary cup of tea which was very nice and were encouraged to buy some tea at the shop. I think the tea here is better than other places but a bit disappointed by the tour.
The factory tour is extremely well presented and any questions from the visitors were well dealt with.  Not to be missed if one has the opportunity to go
The visit was nice but a little bit short. We had a ‚Äúfree‚Äù tea cup at the end of the visit. The views are beautiful from the factory.

Entry to the factory is free. but if you want to enter inside the processing unit and see the different stages of tea leaves processing you will have to pay SLR 250 per head. The entire factory visit will take around 30 minutes time. You will be served complementary tea at the end of the factory visit. there are a lot of places around for clicks. Must visit place in Nuwra Eliya. Preferred time of visit morning till 12 noon.
We went straight to the Tea Boutique and separately ask two staff members for a cup of tea. They each told us to sit and wait then disappeared. Waste of time.
Worth a visit and the guide answered all the questions although I do not know why photos were not allowed to be taken. No pressure was put on us to buy the tea.

The tea factory is an interesting place which provides a tour which is informative. There is a lot of talk about how little the tea pickers earn (~800lkr per day) which seemed like a ploy to get tips, which probably dont find their way to the tea pickers.

Interesting tour round tea factory but the over-zealous guide was obsessed by telling us not to take photos! Accused one young lady of taking them when she hadn't. Must have though we were all competitor spies although there was hardly state-of-the-art innovative machinery to spy on!

There were 2 options - 250 rupees for tea factory or 1000 for tea factory and tea picking. We opted for the latter and picked tea first. The lady took us down and we got dressed in the tea picking clothing, and she only said how to pick tea leaves and then left us to it for 20 mins. She didn‚Äôt explain anything about tea picking or the process. We then walked round the tea factory which wasn‚Äôt active with another uninspired lady who was on autopilot when explaining things. At the end we were given a lovely cup of tea but were not told anything about it. Visited another tea factory in our trip and had a much better experience and learnt so much from an enthisiastic guide who turned on the machine where the factory wasn‚Äôt active for us to help visualise the process, and then we bought tea from there!

On arrival we were given the option of tea factory tour for Rs 250 or tea picking for Rs1000. We went for the latter which turned out to be a huge mistake. We were shown how to pick one tea leaf then left to our own divides for 20 minutes, whilst the guide was preoccupied with her phone. We were not told anything about the tea plantation or the tea picking process. After this we were taken on a tour of the factory, but all the machinery was off as they only use the factory at night. During the tour the guide was more interested with her friends, giggling and waving at them, than giving us any real information about the factory. She also spoke in autopilot and was inspiring. Overall a very disappointing visit and not worth the money. This trip was unforgettable for all the wrong reasons.

Disappointing tour of the tea factory as the guide had a poor English accent and spoke very quickly. Amazingly they did not sell the lovely green smocks which they insisted all visitors had to wear on the tour. BIG missed opportunity.

We visited a number of tea factories and got tired of the hard sell. Pedro tea factory was different. It had a lovely feel. The lady who showed us around was really lovely. There tea is delicious and there was no hard sell at all. Highly recommend

I wasn‚Äôt really into this, but my lady was and the tuk tuk driver recommended it... you‚Äôll take a 15 minute walk through the factory and see how tea is made... they let you have a tasting and hope you‚Äôll buy something.
Honestly we visited 2 tea factories and found this one the best . It was nice , the tour was really nicely done and the estates were soooo pretty and secluded. Totally worth the visit

We went out of our way to visit this tea factory due to a write up in the Lonely Planet.  They did tours, but they were at a cost, and the factory is not in operation during the day, so there is not much to see.  The tea room and gift shop was pretty uninspiring, so we spent about 5 minutes there and left.  Waste of a tuk tuk fare.

We visited the factory in January 2019. De tour guide was very hard to understand because of her poor English. We didn‚Äôt understand a thing.. After the short tour, we got a cup of tea (which was included the tour price of 200rp). The waiter also offered us a fruit cake. We asked if it was including the price and he answered yes. We got a old Christmas cake... when we wanted to leave he told us to pay 450rp for the cake. We complained about it at the cashier but all we‚Äôve got a was a sorry and he couldn‚Äôt speak English reason. We didn‚Äôt get our money back and left the factory with a unsatisfied feeling.

The cafe and the views and setting are the highlight of this trip. The tour with a very uninterested guide and the hard sell afterwards put a dampener on the visit. The tour is free though and you tip as you see fit.

The tour was very efficient, but felt somewhat rushed and that the guide was pretty much just quoting a memorised spiel. The free cup of tea on the verandah afterwards was ordinary, but appreciated, and it does have a good view of the tea plantations. It was interesting to see the factory, but if you can plan to be there after 11am you've got a much better chance of seeing the tea coming in and being sorted. We were a bit early so the first load of the day hadn't yet arrived.
Lovely tea factory with interesting tour which takes place every 10 minutes. Lovely outdoor area to have a cup of tea afterwards.

Paid 250rupees for the tour.. it took about 20min all together.. the lady spoke very fast and rushed the whole process... She also asked whether she could give my change later however she didn't and I forgot about it so I don't know if she does that to everyone for side note to anyone reading this. We got some tea at the end and we didn't even know what kind of tea we we were drinking... The factory was cool inside and that's about it... I guess it's a must do for something to do in Nuwara Eliya. We took a stroll around the tea plantation which was nice and had some sick views of the dam and Mountains.

Visited Pedro Tea Factory staff is simply amazing and well explained the process step by steps. Entry fee for factory visit is LKR 100 for locals and LKR 250 for foreigners. You can taste the tea and sales outlet is there to purchase tea. Good is thing is, lover's waterfall is around the factory. Amazing experience

Great guide who explained everything clearly and concisely.  Sixpacks of tea seem expensive at 2000 rupees but each pack of tea is 125g  for just under ¬£1.50 so good value really for a class product.  Teaworkers were striking in Nuwara Eliya while we were there.  They want 1000 rupees a day instead of the current 850.  I so hope they get it as it is such a hard life.

Visited the tea factory and guided by the volunteer, about how the tea processing takes place ,step by step. Took about 25 minutes to finish the session. Then we were all served, crystal clear golden tea, aromatic and refreshing. Bought some tea packs also.
Chose the Pedro tea factory if you are wanting an authentic experience. Only 200 rupee per person for a guided tour with tea sample at the end.

Average place to see tea garden, little bit of history of tea industry in Sri Lankan hill country. You could walk down the tea bushes. You can buy tea and refresh yourself with a nice and warm cup of tea.
nice loving scenery and the weather was really good. the factory is very traditional as they are still using very basic machinery and process to product tea
Another tea estate with lush green tea gardens. Enjoy the tea testing session and feel the aroma of it
A nice tea factory where they make primarily black tea. Staff is nice which takes you through the factory and explain the process.
Having read mixed reviews we were pleasantly surprised with our visit. Well signposted, easy booking, 250LKR pp, lovely guide, interesting tour and great cup of tea. Good value for money.

A charming tea factory. We did a factory tour followed by a cup of tea then we were able to wander through the nearby slopes watching the women pick tea. The factory was very interesting and so clean.

I‚Äôve been at Pedro Tea Factory to times and it was very interesting both times. It was a friendly guide, who showed us that old and very traditional factory. After the tour you will be invited for a nice cup of tea. Also you can buy tea with a high quality for a reasonable price.

Pedro Tea Factory is not quite as fancy as others in the area but definitely worth a visit. The staff was friendly and helpful. There is a outside area where you can have a cup of tea and enjoy the beautiful view.

A good tour, although rather quick (roughly 20-30 mins). We came on a Sunday so only one machine was working, and no tea picking - not to mention torrential rains. Our tour guide was really informative, giving us plenty of info although it would‚Äôve been nice to hear about more about the founding of the estate and the fermentation process. But for 250lkr and a great cup of tea at the end (which we then purchased for a great price) it‚Äôs definitely worth the trip from Nuwara Eliya. The views are beautiful and I‚Äôm sure during the week when the pickers are out and the weather is more pleasant a stroll around the fields would be worth it. I‚Äôd recommend getting a list of questions you want to ask, as they‚Äôre happy to answer any questions if you find you haven‚Äôt had one answered.

Situated proudly as the tea factory at the highest elevation within Sri Lanka the factory produces some of the best tea in the world. A tour can be organised on arrival to see the process. A tea shop also allows you to taste and buy some tea.

You‚Äôre shown around the processing factory. The tour finishes off in the tea shop where you can then stroll around plantation. We‚Äôre big tea drinkers so we enjoyed it. We even chatted with some of the tea ladies in the fields. Fun fact: their collection bags are attached to their hats (not their backs)

We took this tour and another on the same day, this tour was educational and we learnt a lot about the tea making process which is good however there was no option to walk around the plantation after the tour, it seemed as though it was more effort and nobody came to show us the gift shop either which was strange. The tour cost 250LKR pp. It was a rather hurried trip and we only stayed for around 30 mins from arrival time to leaving. Other plantations offer a more relaxed welcome.

We visited this factory on 4th October and were looking forward to a tour around their site. Unfortunately we didn‚Äôt make it to this point. After buying our ticket for the tour we spent almost 40 minutes sat waiting for it to start, after being told it was a 10 minute wait. After around 30 mins we were told it would be another 5 minutes and waited another 10 before leaving. It was very disappointing to see that they had chosen to prioritise the bus tours over our custom. It also did not help that the waiting area was completely infested with flies. We were given a cup of tea to try whilst we waited, with one of the cups arriving with the previous users lipstick on which is always very appetising. The tea was weak and not particularly enjoyable. All of this mounted together helped our decision to leave without the tour starting. We would recommend there are plenty of other tea factories in the Nuwara Eliya area where they treat all customers with respect.

This place is close to Nuwara Eliya. It‚Äôs a 40 min walk or a quick Auto-rickshaw. Our guy took us there from town, waited for us and took us back to the hotel for 600 rupees. We did a tour which was as only 20 min and really quite interesting. It was 250 rupees each and the woman taking the tour was quite engaging and interesting. Nice cuppa tea at the end. An easy and relatively quick way to see a good tea plantation.

This very old original tea estate offers tours to visitors of the main factory during the day as the tea is actually made at night when it is cooler. Clear explanations of the various levels of tea and a beautiful cup of tea at the end. Stunning location close to town.
Well worth a visit, very informative and interesting. All staff were friendly and no sales pitch at the end too
once completed tour go to the tea house to enjoy a full flavoured tea. staff friendly and helpful. You can purchase tea there.

To be fair, it was interesting and was set in stunning Countryside. We learned about the tea making process and that was an enjoyable experience - but because they make ‚Äòlight‚Äô tea most of the really interesting work and processing is done overnight, meaning the tour was primarily around an empty and quiet factory - more like a museum tour, which is not what it was billed as. Worth it ifyou have time to kill and are in the area, but would not go out of your way. Plus, as always, the shop is very overpriced.
probably best to see during the wek we went on a saturday and nothing working guide was pleasant and tea afterwards refreshing no hard sell which was nice as well

Visited Pedro having been left wanting on a trip to Stone Gate the previous day. Pedro is actually based on the plantation and you can see the tea plants and pickers in action. Good tour and explanation, but machines aren‚Äôt working as the quality of tea they produce is made at night (when cooler to slow down the the fermentation process) and I guess it would be dangerous anyway to walk around a factory in production anyway. Nice cup of tea afterwards, and a very soft sell in the shop, with really good prices. Afterwards had a wander through the tea plants and then walked up to Lovers Leap. Well worth a visit.

One of the reasons we went to Sri Lanka was to see a tea factory in production.  Owing to the type of tea they produce here the production only takes place at night.   We were given a quick tour around looking at inactive machines which made us none the wiser.   You are then left in the reception area to watch a marketing video about how wonderful Pedro is and how they are helping the community etc (and given a cup of tea!).   Given the lack of tea production you see on this waste of time tour, it would be far more useful to show a video of the tea production, at least then you would not feel you were leaving as badly informed as you were when you arrived!   There are tea factories where you can see tea being produced and I suggest you visit one of those!!

Interesting place to visit. We came at about 8:30 AM (visiting hours are 8:00-11:00 AM and also in the afternoon, but I can‚Äôt remember exact hours). We immediately got a guide (entrance fee - 250 rupees per person, but guide is for free, you can leave tips, if you want). The guide was kind and told us everything about the factory clearly and we went through all the steps: from picking leaves to packing a tea. In the end of the tour we could taste a cup of their tea while enjoying the tea fields view from the big windows. You can buy some tea in their shop and have a walk trough tea fields, even talk with the workers. Really nice time we had! It took us ~ 1 hour.

We were only staying about 3 mins down the road from this factory so it was the natural place to visit. Maybe not as grand or as big as some of the other factories, but our experience was excellent. Some days the factory is not in full production and this is due to the weather. When it is full and raining the tea leafs are not growing and therefore are not being picked. It was in half operation when we were there, and the lady who escorted us around for almost an hour was excellent. She advised she was the daughter of parents who had also worked at this factory for many years. She had been there for more than 8 years working also, and had climbed the ladder to a tour guide supervisor. There is a 250lkr  entry fee and that covers the tour and a cup of tea at the end. The lady clearly explained in very good English the full process while taking us through the different drying, rolling, and sorting rooms of the factory. She welcomed our many questions. A worker at the factory or in the field does an 8 hour shift and gets paid 850lkrs for that shift. All workers at this factory live in company provided housing, so while the pay is very low in comparison to most western countries, the workers we spoke to are very happy to have steady work and a roof over their heads. So a great thank you to the senior tour guide at Pedro, well done! We are far more educated now.

When we visited the Pedro Tea Factory the weather was too wet for tea picking so the factory was not operational. Nonetheless we had an excellent guide and it was fascinating to see the equipment and learn about all the different teas and how they process the tea leaves

Interesting to see the factory and get a better understanding of all the process steps for making tea. Unfortunately the factory is running during nighttime, so you do not get to see the process in working, but you get to see all the Machines and get an explenation of all the steps. The tour is finished by getting to try a cup of the from the factory, and you can buy a lot of differnet tea sorts as a souvernier

We visit Pedro tea factory in August 2018. It is only 10 minutes to Nuwara Eliya the factory is working only nights. They made a quick tea factory tour and served a cup of tea at the end of the tour. They are selling also their own tea. You are paying 250 rupies ( less than 2usd)  for person. You may find another place which is free on the way from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya.

Visited early in the morning as an alternative activity to our trip to Horton Plains being cancelled. They were extremely helpful, despite the electricity being off, they managed to make us a hot and welcome cup of tea and a tour of the factory. The tour is free and there is a small shop to purchase the estate Tea from. It is useful to offer the factory guide a small tip of 100/200 rupees. The factory is full of the most original machinery much of which is still in operation today, so if you are a lover of this sort of thing, you would definitely enjoy a visit. I was surprised at how quickly tea leaves are turned into tea, within 24 hours and that the aluminium lined bags they pack the tea into at the end of the process can keep the tea for upto 2 years. The estate announces that it is an ethical company with some opportunity for the workers to be involved and would appear to offer more medical care and education than some others do. I wasn't sure about this place as there were some remarks about the speed of the tour and the guides accent, but we did not feel rushed at all and the guide was clear, helpful and very friendly.

Went round as a small group, unfortunately due to the rain the factory wasn't operating so we couldn't see it in action. However it was good to see and learn about the process & machinery, the guide though wasn't able to tell us anything about the history and was unable to answer a lot of questions.
Our guide was a very poor ‚ÄúEnglish‚Äù speaking lady. The tour was very fast. You do not visit the tea plantation itself, only the factory. Afterwards you might get a cup of tea.

We went into the visit without expecting much; there were mixed reviews so we just hoped it would either be good or funny if it was a total failure. After paying for our tour (250LKR per person) we had to wait for a guide to arrive, although this only took a few minutes. After the guide arrived we went into the factory. It was pretty... empty. It also seemed like the woman who gave us the tour was sick and tired of her job because she zoomed through the factory like a Formula 1 car with rockets strapped on the back. I also think it will be pretty hard for most non-native English speakers to understand what the guide is saying. The whole tour wasn't very convincing, nothing was working and there wasn't much of an impression to be gained from the tour. Moreover, the tour seemed kind of fake, after we noticed the "bags with tea" in the storage room had a text on them saying they were from March 2018. TL;DR - It was a short but decently fun tour, just don't go in with too many expectations because you will most likely be disappointed.

Actually got the chance to go amongst the tea bushes and pick tea leaves if you. I believe not many tea factories allow you to do this but this one does and it is near the town of nuwara eliya so it is very convenient if you‚Äôre staying around town. Didnt go for the tour though as we went for another tour at another factory previously and i dont see how the process would be much different.

We went for a tour to this factory. Our guide was a lady that spoke very unclear english. She guided us at a high speed through the production facility where nobody was working. Only during the night there is production. So after the tour we have seen all the machines but still do not know exactly how the production is being done. Afterwards you receive a cup of tea.
This is an excellent Tea factory experience. The guide Kalai vani was excellent. The view is beautiful. Tea very good. A good experience.

Having spent time at other tea factories in Sri Lanka, we hadn't planned to visit but a miscommunication with our tuk-tuk driver brought us here en route to another activity; we weren't blown away by it and felt that the other factories we visited offer a better experience. We came on a non-production day and joined a tour with one other couple; it was delivered very quickly with very little enthusiasm and was not as interesting or informative as those in other factories we visited. At the end, we were given a cup of tea with no information as to what type of tea it was: more background and details would've been appreciated, or even a tasting of different types of tea. The views around the factory were amazing and it was fascinating to see the estates.
Did the detailed survey of tea factory . where we wereexplained of how the different kinds of tea powders are made
Well worth a visit as it provides a great insight into the tea making process through the guided tour. This was followed by some tea sampling. Pedro is an ethical tea producer so well worth a visit.

While in NE for a workshop, we went over to Pedro Tea Factory to buy some tea. Wow....the place itself was amazing...clean, neatly laid out garden....wonderful tea centre and the  best part - 2 amazing sales women ....most probably from the surrounding plantations. They were so knowledgeable on the tea they were selling ..... As part of the Ethical Tea partnership i think the Pedro Tea Factory is doing a great job ...its just 2 kms from the city centre on the Kandapola Road....A must visit

We really enjoyed the tour of this working factory. We did not appreciate the hard manual work required for tea picking and sorting thereafter. We have all resolved that we MUST pay more for our tea as the tea pickers don‚Äôt get paid enough- it seems less than US$10 per day. Shocking!

You have to pay for the tour but it is cheap and you get a free cup of tea. Was nice and informative/Interesting. The nicest thing was to walk around the tea plantation before/after...very pretty and great views. From here you can walk up to the lovers leap waterfall which is a lovely walk.

I did a number of tours of the tea plantations and tea factories while in Sri Lanka. This was the only one which I had to pay for (though only 200 rupees - about USD $1.25). However it was the most perfunctory. We got the factory tour in a large group (after waiting for others to slowly stop in and accumulate) and one cup of tea at the end. There was a small shop with a limited selection of teas to buy after the tour. On the plus side it has easy access from the closest town Nuwara Eliya and was right in the tea fields. Of the tea factories I visited this had the best access to the tea fields for spectacular views and the opportunity to take close up photos of the lady tea pickers. For that alone it is worth visiting - with your camera or iphone in hand.

I‚Äôve been to several tea factories in Sri Lanka and Pedro is nice as you get to see a working factory. Sadly on the day we went it was not operating due to a public holiday but nevertheless you get to see inside it and you can tell that it‚Äôs not just a display factory like many others I‚Äôve been to. The tour was only 200rps and included a cup of tea at the end (which wasn‚Äôt great). I wouldn‚Äôt buy tea here but if you‚Äôre into your tea and want to see a functioning factory it‚Äôs worth a visit.

We were taken to this plantation and factory by our driver as part of a planned itinery. The tour of the plant was very informative and the guide spoke extremely well. We left very informed, just unfortunate that we didnt see the factory in action (works at night), and couldnt take photos in the factory.  Got to taste some tea (without milk as its not the done way), and walk amongst the plantation. We left satisfied that we had been to what we wanted to see and hear, but feel there could have been more. Sadly didnt see anyone picking leaves, but that was just where we were at the time. All family happy.

We were looking forward to seeing a working tea factory in action, learn about tea and enjoy a tasting to understand different varieties and qualities of tea. None of this actually happened as we were shown around an empty tea factory looking at machines and being told the absolute minimum by a bored and annoyed guide. After the tour we were given a cup of tea and encouraged to buy tea from the shop. Far too commercialise. If you want to learn about tea and enjoy a tea tasting go somewhere else, this was totally not worth the time or energy.

Was heading for the Lover‚Äôs Leap, when I found this tea factory, and thought I‚Äôd buy some to bring back home. Tried to ask if it was organic, the women in the tea saloon didn‚Äôt understand, so after getting a hold on the manager, I sort of Got an answer: they are ‚Äúsort of organic‚Äù he said - using some chemicals. They do seem to have great focus on social responsibility, like houses for all their workers, which is great. Their lightest tea was the best, in my opinion, but also the BOP.

The tour was quite short, but for those who don't know much about how tea is made, the tour is quite informative. The tour costs Rs.200/= which is very reasonable. The young guide who gave the tour was very pleasant and also answered most of the questions. The tour ended with a tasty cup of tea. You can also buy tea from there for about Rs.500/=, but I hear that there are more popular places in Nuwara Eliya that sell better quality tea (a couple of hundred rupees more expensive though!). We definitely came out knowing more about different types of tea. Not sure if the staff noticed, but we enjoyed the tea with the snacks we had brought. We also had our packed lunches outside the tea boutique area overlooking lush green tea plantations. There were bathrooms at the tea boutique and both men/women's bathroom were fairly clean. Overall, it was a great experience.

I came quite late there so the factory was nearly closed but the stuff was so nice to give me a tour - it‚Äôs quite short but interesting. Then you can have a cup of free tea witch is phenomenal!!! Very good experience at Pedro Tea Factory!!!

Pedro tea factory is situated closer to Nuwaraeliya city limits. You can take a tuk-tuk from the town or bus which travels on udupussellawa road. You'll get a brief while moving on a factory visit about the tea making process where you can clarify yourself and finally you can enjoy a hot cup of Ceylon tea as well. :)

It was unfortunate for me as I visited the Pedro Tea Plantation on Good Friday. There is still a factory tour but there was no production and we are only shown all the machines without the tea leaves. If you plan to explore the tea plantation, you might want to wear long pants. To get a nice shot in the middle of the tea plantation, you have to walk in between the super narrow path.

Had just complete the journey on the tea train so where better to go than visit a tea factory.  As we had just stayed for two nights at a tea plantation we only really wanted to visit factory.   We were taken round a by lovely lady (Sivakavi Kalaivani) who spoke amazing English with an occasional word with a Scots accent - lovely to hear.  Not all the machinery was working as it was late in the afternoon but that did not spoil the experience.  Commencing with the drying areas for the tea all the way down to packed product.   When finished we adjourned to Lovers Leap (tearoom) where we tasted several varieties of tea - really delicious.  We had taken with us a iced fruitcake from the UK so what better way to finish the afternoon with Ceylon tea and English cake.  Well worth the visit.

Visited with my dad, and we had a lovely walk down to the tea plantains were we could see the ladies busy at work. They were doing guided tours of the factory for a small price but as the machines were not working we did not join in. We did sit in the cafe and enjoy a lovely cup of tea. Found the service to be a little slow- but pleasant all the same.

We were staying overnight in Nuwara Eliya and borrowed bikes to visit the Pedro tea factory. The ride up the hillside was tough but it was so beautiful to cycle the paths through the plantation we didn't mind. The tour itself lasts about 30 minutes and the smell of the fresh tea is intoxicating in the drying room. Our guide spoke perfect English and was happy to answer questions. After the tour we tasted some of the tea, which was delicious! Definitely worth a visit if you have a free morning.

Its a small factory and when i visited, it was not operational. They showed us around and offered us a cup of tea at the end. Costed 200. It was OK trip and only thing working for it was that this was the closest factory to the city. Many people come by tuk tuk (400-500 Rs) but one can easily find bus from city center which drops you just outside the factory and cost you like 20 rs. The path leading to lovers leap is just opposite to factory (passing through tea plantation of pedro estate) and both activities can be coupled together.

Wasn‚Äôt a high cost for this tour and you get to have a roam afterwards. Our tour guide doesn‚Äôt seem to get that much enjoyment from the job and it felt a little underwhelming but it was still informative and I learnt stuff about tea- which was the point. It‚Äôs good to combine with a loop walk up to lovers leap and then get a tuk tuk back to town

I had already visited two tea factories so i did not bother taking the tour, but i rested in the cafe where i watched a documentary about Pedro Tea Estate and then enjoyed a free cup of tea. However there were quite a few people taking the tour and they seemed satisfied. I hiked here after passing by Lover'sLeap waterfall, but the last kilometer is along a busy road which was not too enjoyable.
A tuk tuk from town should cost about 500 each way. This is a nice tea factory. It's interesting to look around how it all works.

We travelled from Kandy to Pedro tea plantation by train which took us about 4 hours which was great. When we arrived at the tea plantation we were given a cup of tea and a tour of the factory which was rushed and took us twenty minutes. A total waste of time and a waste of my holiday. I was excited that I booked this tour prior to my holiday and I feel totally let down

This was not a very exciting venture. However it was interesting to know that the tea made here is sold and repackaged by big brands. It was also educational to see the process of tea making.  Also the views at the location were great.
We dint know this and ended up just taking a stroll at the tea gardens. You can also buy the tea at the factory.

The people try to force you to do the tour. The place is small and not as beautiful as other tea locations such as Talawakelle Tea Estate and Edinburgh Tea Estate. I would personally avoid and go to the above.

Went there by Tuk-tuk, paid 200 rp per person for a guided tour around and a cup of tea afterwards. The tour takes no longer than 20 minutes and gives you the basic information about the tea making process. Smaller place compared to the big tea factory‚Äôs in the area. I would guess also less tourists. Which we love. After the tour we walked into the plantation and talk to the working ladies. A nice anc cheap experience.

Our guide was friendly and the factory interesting. It did feel like we learnt the rudiments of the process and given we only had a limited time, this worked for us. If you want a more in depth bus-to-cup tour, you'll have to look elsewhere.

I have visited the Pedro factory twice now, once with my partner and a second time with my Mum. It is very reasonably priced at just 200rs for a 20-30 minute guided tour and cup of tea. Our guide Kalaivane was superb! Friendly, informative and the daughter of a tea picker so able to gave a very personal and honest account of the tea industry. An enlightening experience I would definitely recommend!
Visited this factory... they give you a tour inside the factory where you can see how tea is made and you can enjoy different types of tasty teas.
Lovely, quaint, old tea factory. Tour was very informative and views were fantastic. Tea quite expensive.
Good tour and an interesting insight into how tea is picked and prepared for packaging. Also has great views of the tea estate and a nice place to relax and drink tea (what else)

We visited the factory with a group and there is no doubt the surrounding area is stunning and everyone is very pleasant I was struck by the emphasis their signs made about how ethical they are I am reliably informed that the pickers are paid only 500 SLR a day - the equivalent of A$5 and not paid if they are sick Our guide was so ill she had not have sit down breaks so she would not collapse This same multi national company still has its office workers using a typewriter with carbons and a manual ledger!

Short (15 min) visit to the factory for 200 LKR per person with a free cup of tea afterwards on a terrace with beautiful view. Our guide looked little bit annoyed. Not allowed to take pictures inside. It is easily reachable by public bus from the city centre (around 25 LKR per person, 15min). You can also take a walk from here to the Lover's Leap watterfall.

We paid ¬£26.71 per person for 6 people for a private tour.  The tour company didn't realise it was a public holiday and so there were no pickers on site and the factory wasn't working.  There were people on site who greeted us and actually did give us a tour but, not realising we had pre-booked the visit, they said it would cost us SLR200 each - i.e. approximately ¬£1!  So - in essence, we paid ¬£25 for a very expensive taxi ride from our hotel to the tea plantation approximately 3 km away!  You can turn up at the Pedro Tea Plantation at any time and be given a tour for SLR 200 and the price of a Tuk Tuk from town.  Having said that, the tour was very interesting.

There is no signage to this effect, but you buy your ticket (Rs. 200) in the nicely located tea shop.  It took a while to get to it, as people line up to ask for prices of the various tea packages.  Apparently, management does not want to put the prices on the shelves, but rather have each customer approach the cashier to ask. The entrance ticket is amusing. There's a list of admonishments about proper behavior in the factory, including "Do not waste time inside the Factory." After a short wait we got an apron to put on, and joined a large group on the tour.  We were about 20 visitors, too many to always hear the guide.  She spoke good English, but sometimes her voice was drowned out by the machinery. The best part of the visit was the nice cup of tea on the terrace overlooking the lovely plantation

We took the factory tour with a knowledgeable guide. The process really is visible and makes you start to think twice about what goes into our staple cups of tea. The tea pickers have back-breaking work, nevertheless they are happy to welcome you to their world. You can get a nice selection of teas from the shop - without any pressure selling.

The plantation is very beautiful and you can also visit by your own walking through the fields. The visit at the factory does not cost so much but it's really too short and at the end we had just a cup of tea (same for everybody, you cannot choose). You can buy tea, but the prices are a little bit higher than in other stores.

The tour guide from the tea factory has strong accent. It's very hard to understand what she said. The facilities inside the factory are good though. However, the souvenir shop was disappointing. Very few options and no price tag there. Also they use special names for different types of tea so even harder to know what types of tea they are. The only advantage is this tea factory is not too far. We have been to Bluefield tea garden and ceylon tea museum in Kandy. Those are much better places to buy tea in terms of varieties and prices.

The guided tour is about 40 minutes and it costs 200 rp per person. At the end you can have a cup of tea. It's interesting if you haven't visited one already. The area all around it's very nice and you can walk around the tea plantations!

We didn't try excursion there as it costs 300 rupees and we visitrd Bluefield earlier for free. But we really enjoyed the tea plantation view downhill (not such impressive like Lipton's seat but also good).

An enjoyable guided tour around an authentic tea factory. All the equipment is on display and the guide explains what its used for, though what is operating depends on the time of day. The cup of tea at the end of the visit is outstanding. Be aware that you can't take photographs in the factory though.
Since we arrived together with the westerner groups we, can see the favoritism in entertaining guests by the staff.

We got to the tea plantation and the ladies at the counter told us that the machines were off, so if we wanted to, we could still pay to enter but no tour was going to be offered because the production had finished. We hung out at the lounge and had a cup of tea but it's a level of poverty tourism that I am not comfortable with. All you can see are the tea plantations and the women that work there. If you read a little bit about it, you'll realize that these women are very underpaid. So you end up sipping a cup of tea looking down on the workers from a viewing deck. Not really my kind of thing to do, so I'll just advice you to avoid it altogether. The tea plantations in themselves are beautiful-ish. They're green trees... there are only so many pictures you can take of green trees.
Good place to visit, you are taken round the factory to see the process. You get to try some tea on the verandah. Good little shop to buy the different teas. Staff were lovely
The tour is short and I would have wanted a bit more info about the history and cultivating of the tea.

Non operational in the morning. Opening Hours: 8.30 AM Ticket: LKR 200/- with one cup of tea If you don't want to visit the factory, you can still visit the tea plantation without any charges. You can tip the workers in the plantation if you like. The hike in the fields in amazing.

Should only visit this place if you have never been on a tea factory tour before. The guide was not very enthusiastic and could not communicate very well in English/answer questions that were not in the part of her script. The factory tour itself was very short and not very informative. Since the factory operates only at night we couldn't see any machine working or the end product from a particular machine. Maybe they should have kept samples from each stage for visitors to understand the various processes better. Nonetheless the view from their tasting area balcony was really nice and you were welcome to walk amongst the tree bushes

We had a good, informative, good English speaking tour round Pedro tea factory. Tour was not free as like in other tea factories but ticket was not expensive. They took us through each stage of the tea making process answering all our questions along the way

I really enjoyed a brief but informative visit and was happy to see a working factory and the tea making process in action. My new found knowledge will allow me to make more informative selections in the future and I will enjoy the taste even more now knowing how much hard work goes into my daily cuppa. There are numerous tea plantations in this area and many factories I can't imagine they vary much so suggest you pick whats is on route and convenient.

The tea factory is among a huge tea plantation. They take you on the tour in groups, while waiting for your turn or after the tour you can relish their complimentary tea drink. There is an fee of 200lkr that is charged, so in case you plan on visiting other places in Nuwara Eliya then one of the bigger tea plantations would be a better option since the tours here dont have charges.
