A good insight into how demanding tea picking and processing really is. Thank you to the excellent guide who showed us round and answered our questions really well.

If you are after a substantial tea plantation and factory tour this isn't it, but if you want a quick half hour look inside a factory and cup of tea for 200RS this will do! Our guide was friendly, knowledgeable and some great English. Shame it couldn't be more substantial and feature tea tasting or this would be a winner
Very interesting. Tour takes about 15 minutes and cost 200rupes per person. Tea reasonably priced if looking for tea purchases.

We visited two tea factories, one of them was "Pedro". The place is very nice, attention is excellent and you can have a complete vie of the tea process production. Very convenient to understand how it arrives to your cup.

As I am engaged in the tea sector ,I was much interested about this place but when I tasted the cup of tea I got much dissatisfied as they offered us a cup of tea made of Tea "DUST" thats one of the low cost tea which tastes awful and I totally disappointed with this experience. But I must say the view through the tea shop was quite nice  but i went there for tea so if you are looking for great cup of tea ..sorry ,thats would not be the place for such.

My fianc√© said that he felt sorry for taking me to this place. Number one, the service was delayed and we felt ignored. Then to make things really bad, the tea was hopeless. No aroma, no color and it was utterly tasteless. Having so many tourists in the facility, the ladies washroom didn't have any toilet rolls, no hand washing soap and hand towels to dry. Hayleys, what a shame. And please don't put water in the soap dispenser. Disgusting.

The tour of the Old Tea Factory was good for those who have yet to visit one, the guide was informative and took time to explain. At the end of tour, you get a free cup of tea at the visiting lounge that has a fantastic view of the Pedro tea estates. We paid Rs200/pax for an afternoon well spent.

It was quick and short visit at the Tea Factory. It was good to see the machines and understand the process of making tea.In the end i manage to buy the finish product at their store in the same area. Although the machines were not working at the time of my visit at least I was able to see how the tea making process in reality. Its a good learning experienced and one of a kind. I visited the tea plantation as well along the road. Very nice atmosphere all green everywhere.

The visit was very quick and hard to understand. Machines are not working during the visit because they work only in night time. They offer a very good cup of tea after the visit, and you can buy tea also but it's expensive. We preferred the visit of Dambatenne tea factory in Haputale.

Wonderful visit set in a wonderful area. Staff friendly and a great tour around the working tea production. Tastings offered of various teas and the opportunity to purchase. Really enjoyed the tour and very well explained how teas are dried and prepared. Highly recommended and thank you for allowing the public to visit.
Good tour, very short but explain everything well. Interesting to see inside the factory and you can try the tea at the end. Only 200rupees

A tea plantation must be visited if you are in the area. We visited Pedro Tea Factory. Our guide was informative. We were able to see the different stages of tea processing, even though only some areas of the factory were working that day. You really don't need to see all the stages, as they are well explained and samples of the different types of tea are available to examine. You can taste a cuppa at the end of the tour and even wander in the beautiful plantation and take photos. If you do take a picture of a worker, offer them a bit of money. These women only earn $5 a day if they meet their quotas. It's back-breaking work.

Make sure before you pay for the tour that you check that it actually is a production day. We payed only to find it was not even in operation that day. It was informative even though it wasn't running.

Not being much of a tea drinker, I found the factory tour interesting and informative.  But what fascinated me more were the tea pickers who worked 8 hours a day with a daily goal of picking 18 kilograms a day, all for less than $5 USD.

Good place for a walk. Wandering amongst the tea fields and up to the waterfall was a tealightful experience. Went to get a cuppa after and it came with a free tour (200rps). Tour was short but informative and guide was pleasant. Sat down salivating in anticipation of our post tour beverage but unfortunately it failed to materialise. Asked the waitress twice but it appears it takes more time to make a cuppa than it does to dry and process tea. We sacked it off and went to town for lunch.

There are several competing tea factories that are vying to be the top tourist draw of tea country (massive hotels, all the trappings).  This one, while perfectly well set up for tourists, is clearly still mainly in the business of processing tea.  They have a nice reception area, and start you off with a cup of delicious local product.  Then they take you on a very informative tour, on which pictures are inexplicably forbidden (most of the machinery appears to date back to the early industrial revolution, I can't imagine a picture or two would disclose any top secrets but oh well). Guide books say nothing is going on because they do all their processing at night, but I actually saw this as an advantage:  no interference, we could walk around and not get in anyone's way.  Our guide was very knowledgeable.  Strongly recommended!!

Machines were not working when we did the tour. It was short, but it gives you an idea about the proces. It only costs 200 rupees, including a cup of tea. I would do it in combination with Lover's Leap falls.

We were not so impressed with the tour at this factory. First of all the factory was not in action. I guess because it was a Sunday. So you look at a bunch of machines and try to figure out how it works. The tour leader was very hard to hear because of the noise of cleaning the machines. The good thing is that Pedro works in a very friendly way for the environment, fair trade and so on. The tour itself was however not so great.

I don't think it's worth it, but it is just 200 roepies. You will guided through the trees factory, she will tell something about the price of producing tea. But her English is not really good, it's a script. You can't understand it, it think Google helps you more about the proces.
I visited 02 times to this place.Beautiful Sorrounding.Guides explain about tea process A - Z. Worth to Visit.

Nice tea factory to visit. Thought I preferred the Ceylon Tea Museum near Kandy. But if you are in Nuwara Eliya and you didn't already visited something like that, don't hesitate it's worth a visit. The view there is also really nice.

The tea plantation has beautiful scenery and perhaps walking around the grounds was better than the tour itself. When we visited, the factory was not running, due to the poor weather meaning the tea was not grown correctly. However, we were only told this after our tour had begun which we found slightly cheeky. The tour guide was very lovely and informative however, and the tour is finished with a very refreshing cup of their own tea. They were then very helpful in booking us a cab to the train station. Would definitely recommend to anyone staying in Nuwara Elia.
Worth a visit. Old tea company- see how tea is made and the different qualities of tea. Tour of the factory. Not too comercial.

We stopped here for a couple of hours on our way from the station to our hotel in Nuwara Eliya. This plantation was one of the first and we given a nice cup of BOP before a guided tour of the whole process from picking to packing. Very informative and interesting even for our eleven year old son. We were also able to wander the hillsides and get close to pickers afterwards which was great.

The visit to the tea estate was somewhat delayed but the tour guide was very patient and it was encouraging to see how she was self developed. The lack of water and toilet paper in the toilets was a little disconcerting.

Of all the tea factories, this one felt most genuine, not a tourist trap at all! Totally recommended, interesting overview of a tea factory's ins and outs, set to a beautiful view, with a lovely cup of tea as a finale!

Surrounded by beautiful tea plantations, the Pedro Tea Factory was a great place to visit. We had a lovely friendly tour guide who took us round the factory, although by the time we got there, it wasn't actually in use. Our guide was knowledgeable and explained everything really well, and the tea at the end was a lovely treat!

Thanks to our guide who was knowledgeable we left with a good understanding of the Tea Making process.  The factory is clean, staff are helpful and efficient and the complementary Tea is fabulous! 200 rupees and the best tour we did!
Nice quite old factory. Very interesting to see how tea is produced. Beautiful tea gardens with many traditionally clothed women.

Very poor guided tour as only the basics of tea manufacturing was explained. The floors were wet and unclean. At the tea boutique the tea was overpriced. Nothing of the history of this great estate was shared. The guides though were courteous and polite. They need to be supplied with more information.

The tea at the end of the tour was surprisingly refreshing! The tour was a bit shorter than we expected. Also we went on a day when the factory was technically closed so we didn't get to see things in action - pick your day wisely.

This factory is rich in history. I must admit that the factory is very well run and please do join the tour, which is very informative. At the end of the tour, you will be served with a cup of very fragrant tea. The estate itself is beautiful....very green with a panaromic view of the area. I have visited a couple of tea factories in my life and in fact, this is the best of the lot. It is a "must-see" when you are in Nuwara Eliya

I was a bit disturbed that they call these factories plus staff housing "estates" when in reality its modem plantations. Please ask your guide for more info... they don't hide information about the setup of these "estates". All staff seem happy and at peace, grateful even, for the accommodations and the work. Please take the factory tour - very informative - from start to finish. You learn the entire tea process. The best part is learning how tea "tasters" from all over Sri Lanka have such a delicate palate they can identify any tea from any region by taste and smell. I love the sustainability museum at the end of the tour. It's nice to see that such hard work and production is done with the environment in mind.

We visited the tea factory in August 2016. It was lovely and very informative! Unfortunately, we arrived at the factory the day after Poya day, so there was no tea to process. I think the whole tour lasted about 45 minutes and you get a free cup of tea to taste afterwards.

First we were treated to a lovely cup of tea in the waiting area.  We were given aprons and then taken on an informative tour through the tea factory.  We saw different stages of tea production and were explained just how time consuming and precise a process it is.

Nearby the town and a great place to spend an hour or so during a rainy monsoon morning. Pleasant tea caf√© and beautiful views; interesting to see how tea is processed (but be warned going upstairs is one of the hottest experiences ever -- the warm air from the drying process drifts upwards and literally a bit hard to breathe)!

The walk through the tea factory followed by the cup of tea is a wonderful experience. The guides take you around the place which costs LKR 200 (only cash). Your tea comes with the mildest variant that they produce so it's something that you need to keep in mind

They first take you on a tour around the place showing you how tea leaves are taken through various processes and result in the final product-tea powder.After that they give you a hot cup of tea which is very soothing and refreshing.They also sell tea packets freshly prepared in the factory at a nominal price.Overall a good way to spend  1 hr!!!

Had a nice cup of tea - Lover's leap which is only sold in Pedro tea factory. Visiting tea factory is okay, we were guided by a Tamil women with detailed history and tea making process. The only point is photography is not allowed - which is not forbidden in other tea factories. It's the nearest tea factory you can reach from center, take bus in bus stand (ask them which bus to go, 10 Rs and journey is less than 10mins) After visiting finish, you could take a easy walk downward to city center , which only takes 40 mins with 3-4km.

We stopped and had a tour of this working tea factory which was really interesting.  It has been in operation for many years and had some of the old equipment around. Our guide was interesting but I had hoped that we could have a tasting of the different teas.  Maybe next time.

The walk in the plantation, though unassisted is the best thing for those looking for serenity and quiet! Lush green, with majestic pineladen mountains for a backdrop, it cannot get calmer! The tea shop has awesome and courteous staff, and amazing tea. Prices very well against the commercial ones we stopped at on the way-at peradeniya! This one is simple, crisp, and warm!! Cant miss.

I enjoyed visiting Pedro Tea factory and it was really informative visit . The tour took around an hour . They greeted us with a free cup of tea that we enjoyed at their amazing terrace and then the tour began, After the tout they offer us six types of tea and we chose three types to buy. If you are travelling with kids , the visit will be really nice to them.
We really enjoyed the tour. The lady was so proud of her culture and heritage, it was lovely. Nice grounds and walks in the area.
Went here in the afternoon. No tour available. Shop is small, offers some tasting. Tea is quite nice actually. Not worth going out of your way to get her; if you are in the area, ok.

It's easy to get here either by local bus (just say you want to get off at Pedros) or by tuk tuk 300 each way. The tour is 200 & takes 20mins. It's not the most informative & you can't take photos, but it is good to see the old machinery & it does give you a feel about tea production. At the end you do get a cup of tea, which wasn't the best I've tasted so didn't tempt me to buy their tea at the shop. Definitely worth doing & across the street is the start of lovers leap walk.

Small charge to look round (200 rupees per person). Kitted out with hats and aprons and then shown each stage of production as a small family group which was lovely... no big tour. Only takes about 30mins. Very hot in the baking area but thoroughly interesting seeing each step. Welcome cuppa at the end!

Given the importance of tea to Sri Lanka it seemed odd not to try and learn a little about the history of the industry, the people who work in it and the journey it makes from the beautifully cultivated hillsides to our daily brew. This tour, which took around 2 hours touches on most of the those topics. Having been warmly received in a very modern facility, we were each given a gown to wear and ushered off in a small group tour of the facility. This starts with learning about the picking process and the pickers, moves to the drying and a discussion about what makes each type or grade of tea, to the rolling, sorting and packing. Our tour guide was a 4 th generation lady who was excellent and handled even the toughest question with an interesting answer. We liked her a lot as it was obvious what she was doing mattered to her. With the tour over you get to enjoy a nice cuppa. If you are in the area you really should do one of these tours and this one is pretty decent.

We toured the facility which has been in business for more than 150 years. We watched the process from collection to drying and processing leading to the final products (no pictures allowed). We got to taste and purchase the real Sri Lankan tea.  People were very pleasant and the views over the tea plantations beautiful. A must stop if you are in the area.
english was ok, but the guide was not very motivated the group was huge most people did not get what was said there are better visits!!
Thanks to the Pedro tea factory staff. It was very informative tour inside of the factory (20 minutes).

First, take in the great views of the adjacent lush countryside and then take the tour which explains all one needs to know about the history and production of tea in Sri Lanka! The staff guide was most knowledgeable and responsive to questions.

The Tea factory offers a tour explaining the picking and processing of tea leaves, and has a store to purchase their tea products. The tour costs Rs. 200 per person. The tea is processed at night to take advantage of the cooler temperatures, and so the processing operation (except ambient drying) was not operational during the tour.  Besides, the tour guide was not very clear about description of the process. A cup of tea is offered at the end of the tour. In my opinion, charging a fee to tour a non-operational facility makes this factory unwelcome as a place to visit, when there are so many other factories in the area.

Although a paid attraction, this is well worth the spend (200) with a professional guide and freedom to roam the tea plantation afterwards. Met with some tea pickers who were very happy to pose for pics (a tip will be expected for this) and explained how tghey choose the leaves etc. The Duke of Edinburgh visited this factory in 1954 as the small exhibition of paper cuttings and photos shows - an interesting addition to the tour.

We enjoyed our tour of the factory although our guide was a quietly spoken girl. Afterwards, we were given a cup of tea in a pleasant little restaurant. Very nice. Takes about 15-20 minutes to do the tour.

It is worth a visit as you get to see inside the factory and are taken through the whole tea production process. Then you get a cup of tea to taste and it is delicious. The tour and tea are free and given with the usual lovely Sri Lankan smile!

We went there by bus for just a few rupees from Nuwara Elya bus station. Nothing special, but nice to see and get a tour through the factory. The tour costs 200 LKR per person and takes around 30 minutes. Afterwards you get a tea in their small shop.

After a wonderful train trip into the high country this tour did not in any way live up to our expectations. It was a rushed tour with the explanations of the workings of the plantations and the origins of Sri Lankan tea sadly lacking. We were taken around the facility but ended up with no further knowledge than we had arrived with. We were not shown any tea bushes or how they were picked. Sad to say the least as we had looked forward to this part of our journey. A video would have been altogether more enlightening .

Nice view from the estate but the girl giving the tour of the factory felt quite uninterested. Informative but with no engagement. Okey. Assume there a more genuine Tea factory options around. No tasting, only one cup served after finishing the stort tour.
We enjoyed the factory tour and the history of the very first tea factory in Sri Lanka very clear explanation and then tasting on terrace overlooking the tea plantations better than expected

A very good tea factory, working mainly in the night. The tour costs 200 rupees, but include a complimentary excellent cup of tea, and the plantation grounds are very well tended and magnificent to look at.

The various reviews describing the rush in which the "tour" was made and the one cup of tea to "taste" should really have been a warning. But we thought everybody has a bad day someday, and wanted to give it a try. Bad idea. Badly organized staff, lack of communication among them, being indeed rushed through factory halls where only very few woman and machines were actually working. The lady showing us around spoke complicated to understand and with a very low voice. Heard a bit about the process but nothing at all about what makes a good tea, what are the different variations, about the company, and its (fair??) trade, the working conditions... Nada. After maximum 10min we were "done". Got one single cup of tea, no chance to do a tasting. And guess what, it wasn't even a good tea. Had we had an idea where else to go, we would have done that. So, at least we can warn other future visitors.

If you're a tea drinker check this establishment out. The tour of the factory by an informative guide is well worth the time and the short trip out of town. The vistas are beautiful, however the shop only sells several packets of tea at a time, so if space in your luggage is limited you'll be disappointed.

We simply turned up and tours were running pretty much all the time (every 15 minutes roughly, each time enough people we waiting for them to run one), it was 200 LKR each (we visited on 16-02-2017) and the tour rook about 20 minutes. After the tour they gave us free tea to try and we went for a walk around the tea gardens. You can buy all the tea they grow there. The tour was in English.

Apparently the cycle of picking, drying and generally bashing the leaves into bits is all over by about 09:30.  But the factory tour is still open and it is interesting to see the various antique machines standing ready to spring into life next dawn.  The tour includes a cuppa in the picturesque waiting area, which is nice.
Nice to know how our tea is gathered, processed and sent to the auction house in Colombo.  Best of all was the cup of tea at the end
Very interesting visit here finished with a lovely cup of their own home grown produce! Recommend a visit here.
you pay a small price and they take you on a tour. There are certain times which I forgot which had the actual processing but I think the process at night and stop in the morning for new batches.
Very informative although the factory mostly works at night for climatic reasons. It is a pity that they don't sell their own tea after the visit.

The explanation provided by the factory team is very instructive...especially that team shows guests the real-life machinery and the real process they adopt...the team member who led us was a real subject matter expert and talented in explaining and answeting questions..After knowing well the industry and various types pf Tea, it's time to taste an amazing local Tea while enjoying the unlimited Green of this noble plant...spread into big and wide valleys...memorable experience for us and our kids as well..

We had a very interesting morning here, the tour was informative and not too long, the factory still using machinery from the 1950s which are works of art in themselves. From the tea factory it's a good walk to Lovers Leap waterfall where you can see tea pickers at work. It's an easy bus ride from Kandy.

On arriving we were given a cup of the plantation tea, which was delicious, and we were able to sit out on the balcony overlooking the plantation and enjoy the morning sunshine and lovely views. The tire was interesting although quite short, I would have liked to also have a chance to learn about how they pick the tea and look after the plants (it focuses on the processing of the tea after it is picked). Still very interesting however. It can be hard to hear the guide on the factory of you have a large group. The factory promotes worker welfare and ethical tea practices, there are interesting signboards in the visitor centre about the factory's history and engagement in UN programmes.

-We went as a couple -A free tea at arrival was very nice and is for sale -the factory tour was very cheap and it lasted about 30mins. The lady doing the tour was very nice and the tour was informative -we had a short walk around the tea fields and its beautiful -i would recommend visiting this tea factory Thanks Sam
For 100rp you get a 20min tour of the production process from them delivering the tea from the field to the packaging.  Was interesting.

Pedro is geared up to show parties around a totally functioning tea factory.   Good guide but plenty of climbing and no photography allowed.  A visit gives you an idea of the whole, very quick process of producing packed tea from fresh leaves, ending with the sobering fact that the guide would have to work two days to earn enough to pay for a packet of the best English Breakfast tea.

Beautiful experience of watching ladies picking tea leaves (very friendly to chat to) walking through fields and understanding the tea process. After the tour a complimentary cup of tea was provided. Very enjoyable tour. Advice to come there before 4pm if you want to see the machines still working.
Lovely cup of tea pn arrival with a beautiful view of the plantation. The tour was informative and the guide was terrific.
The place is a working tea  factory. They make a real effort to be both welcoming and informative. You get a well explained tour of the whole factory and emerge with a better understanding about tea.

I'm sure I would give this a higher score if we had find in a different day (on a group trip so no choice about that). The factory is basically shut on Sundays so nothing is working and you just get a short talk about the process. Would be much more interesting to see it all working.
Our appointed guide gave us a clear explanation of each step of the process from the tea field to the cup

We were a bit disappointed by this tour of the tea estate. Most of the areas of production were not operating and we found the man who was taking us around difficult to understand. He was speaking in English and we were the only people in the group who had English as our first language so I would imagine the other people understood even less.

Our guide had excellent English and understood our intricate questions about the production of tea.  This was a nice shortish tour (30mins?) where we could really see what happens at night when the tea is processed.  Free cuppa at the end.

This place was great, if anything it is underpriced and compared to many places we visited in the country they couldn't triple the entry price to ¬£3 and it would still be just as popular. We got to don trendy aprons so we looked just like the rest of work workers there before infiltrating the plantation! We got to see how tea was made from start to finish although we couldn't take pictures and so Mrs V is going to have to put up with PG tips as opposed to me starting up my own UK based tea production plant from our 3 bed house! What a disappointment! Despite this we really enjoyed the trip as well as the tea we got to try at the end of it. After you visit ask for directions to the waterfall, it's an easy amble or if your mega lazy you can get a tuk tuk. Happy travels, Mr and Mrs V

We visited with 2 young children and they enjoyed the tour.  We were lucky when we arrived as they were just finishing up the processing of the tea and the warmth and smells from the tea were fantastic.  The tour was informative but not too informative that it became boring, you moved quite quickly from one station to the next, the guide we got was great.  Lovely views over the plantation. Enjoyed a fresh tea complimentary after the tour, doesn't taste like tea I have every experienced before.
Gorgeous destination to take in the beauty of the tea fields. Lovely, knowledgeable guide and a refreshing tea served at the end best enjoyed out on the deck in the sun. A worthwhile activity
We really enjoyed our tour here and the tea was great. Very informative. The views were so beautiful around the factory.

The tour itself is quite disappointing as the factory works only during the night so the machines are inactive. Nor do you get to see the tea fields up close. So it's more of a 15 minute theoretical lecture on the art of tea making. You don't even get to see the tea leaves across the various stages of manufacturing to try and visualise the process. The tour guide is polite and speaks decent English. We had a really poor experience as at the end of the tour we were just left to our own devices and based on having read previous reviews we knew we were supposed to head back to the tea house for a cup of tea. Ended up waiting for approximately 25 mins and no one even bothered to attend to us. Left the place disappointed and empty handed as we really weren't inclined to pick up any tea from the gift shop after being treated so poorly.
A good tour of a tea factory, giving an insight into the tea making process. The guide spoke good english and was very informative.

We were there around 9.30 am.Morning is better, less visitors and can enjoy quit a lot.Parking is also easy when you go early.Everyone has a nice and pleasant smiley welcome.Local entrance is Rs.50 and for the foreigners is Rs.200.Have to wear green color Apron to visit inside and a guild comes with visitors and he explains very well how to make tea step by step. Explanation was really good.After the visit they will provide really nice cup of tea and you can sit their front office and enjoy it.There has a very clean washroom and nice surrounding with tea estate,Hills,Mist.. (Sunday workers are not working in factory but you can go and see inside)

We loved taking a long walk through the tea fields, there is a lake you can walk to which is beautiful and, if walking isn't your thing, the views from the tea house at the top are just incredible! Plus their tea is delicious and just what you need to warm you up as it's a bit chilly up there.

Enjoyed our visit here , nice cup of tea, interesting tour,no hard sell,  sadly the tea picking women get paid a pittance for long hours in the baking sun  and its hard to witness such harsh treatment and then forget about it. I'll never take my morning tea for granted again.
Definitely worth a visit. For 200 Rupees per person you get about 30 minutes of explanation while walking through the factory and a cup of tea afterwards. Money/value is good in my opinion.

This is an interesting place to go & find out more about the making of black tea in a beautiful setting among some vintage machinery. The guide was excellent - patient  & very happy to answer questions. Tips: As production is overnight you don't see much action. No pics inside but great shots from balcony afterwards. Stop close to the factory to snap tea pickers at work

We went to the place with my family i.e my wife, two daughters aged 8 and 12. Finding the place was not difficult and they have the parking. We went there at around 1pm and we were welcome and served with a plain tea which was very good. Ticket was Rs 50/= to visit the factory. We were given green colour apron which I think for food safety. We were guided by their facilitator and he explained the process very well. If you are not familiar with the tea process this is food place to visit special children loved it.

We walked here from our hotel, it was quite a walk but the scenery was beautiful. At first we weren't sure where to go when we entered the tea plantation grounds but we found the ticket counter in the tea shop. Tickets were 200 rupees each. A lady took us round the factory explaining what each machine does and the journey of the tea leaves from picked to packaged. The guide spoke pretty good English and knew enough about the equipment. The equipment was all switched off as the factory process the leaves at night due to the type of tea they make but it was still enjoyable enough. At the end you get a free cup of tea to taste. We walked back passing the waterfalls which was beautiful. Follow our journey on Instagram @twolotllamas

We visited the tea factory in November 2016.  I found it very upsetting the tea pickers are very poorly paid.  We were told by our guide of the tour by the time you are 40 their backs have gone and go no longer work.  The machinery is so out of date (no photos allowed of the machinery).  I just felt they are like modern day slaves it definitely made me think how lucky we all are with our housing and way off life.

We really enjoyed our visit to the tea factory. Its very calm and charming place. The lady took us to the factory tour thru all the processes and nicely explained the various tea categories. It ends with a hot cup of BOP tea!

It was our third tea factory (we were bored :D) and the guiding thing was like any other, nothing special, only thing we didn't like is that all their production is over night so prepare you won't see much action. Anway, this estate has the most beautiful landscape so far, it is worth going there just for the view and good pictures ;). Take a walk a sit on the balcony sippingh the tea and enjoying the view. Beautiful Sri Lanka, it really is!

Perched on top of a hill a little away from the city center this tea garden is among one of the best in Sri Lanka. With a tour fee of LKR 250 the guide takes you through the factory with its century old machinery which are still in use. The tea produced here is a lovely light one - which you can sample for free. Another quirk about this factory is that they allow you to move very freely among the tea plantation. On a cloudy day this is amazing
A quaint place with lovely ,friendly staff. Amazing how much trouble people go to for us to have a cup of tea :-)
This is not a working factory and therefore not very interesting. They are more interested in selling the tea. Very disappointed. It should be classed as a poor museum.

We coupled this tour with a hike up to Lovers Leap waterfall. This was a great experience - the tour was very informative and they answered all our questions very well. You also get to sample the tea afterwards. Don't buy the tea from there though, it's a bit too expensive!

When we went there the factory was closed, so we just visited the sales center and bought some items. Some people were going into the factory although it was not functioning at the time. We had to settle for another factory another time.

It's just a tea factory and there is a catch.  They take you for a tour of the factory and show you, in real time, how black tea is processed.  At the end , they do serve you tea and you have the opportunity to buy some to take away.  Not too bad as loose leaf tea is getting increasingly more difficult to find in some countries.

Pedro Tea Estate is close to Nuwara Eliya - a 10 minute drive maximum. We had a guided factory tour which was quite interesting despite it being presented by a not very interested in us young woman. Afterwards we enjoyed a cup of tea in their tea caf√© overlooking the tea garden. We were allowed to wander through the tea gardens on our own. Allow 1 hour for all. They also have a shop but you have to purchase tea in packs of 3 or 6 which is quite a lot if you have limited luggage room or are still travelling on. I thought this ridiculous and gimmicky to make you have to buy more than you want. Otherwise it's very pleasant to visit.

We did the tour which was very detailed and clear. There is a 500 rupees entrance fee per person and u get a cup of tea at the end. They have a nice collection of tea to buy at their store. A nice place.
Impressive history. Lovely view from the terrace. Great shop. We bought lots of teas and are enjoying them at home with fond memories.

A tour of the Pedro Tea Factory was quite interesting, but rather rushed. We were the first visitors at 8.00 am. The young guide explained the different stages of how the tea is processed and what the various machinery does. No photos are allowed inside the factory. The actual production occurs during the night so we did not see any of the workers or the machines in action. The views from the outside grounds are lovely. Other tea factories may offer a more comprehensive insight
This place offers tours of a tea plantation and then a cafe area to sample the products.  OK for an hour or so if you are in the area.

We traveled from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya by train and saw beautiful hills covered with tea plantations. From Nuwara Sliya we took tuk-tuk to Pedro Tea Factory. Factory tour was very short, year was to dry so we couldn't see entire process of tea preparation.View from factory and tea degustation were very nice.

Very informative visit. Unfortunately machinery was being maintained and cleaned  when we visited so we did not see it in full production but that is probably a blessing - the machines generate and need a lot of heat to do the drying of the tea. Felt sorry for the staff - very poorly paid compared to our standards.

If you're used to factory tours this a bit different - the end-to-end process (which is interesting) is largely carried out on machinery from the early 20th century.  Very interesting visit - and of course you can buy all kinds of tea!

They have a simple yet complicated tea factory, for a price of 200/- we can get a chance to look around and know how teas are being made, we were unlucky and couldn't see the live process as workers were off duty but the lady who gave us a tour was so good at explaining. And the fun part was we were offered tea made from freshly brewed leaves right after the tour in there main building which is located in a very beautiful place surrounded by nature all over.
Its look amazing big mountain around factory near factory there is tea shop you can order tea its frash tea and nice teste
Great activity in Nuwara Eliya, very reasonable price to enter (200 LKR) included a guided tour and free cup of tea. You can also walked around the plantations. Very close to lover's leap waterfall.

One of several tea factories I visited in Sri Lanka. Beautiful location, great pictures over the tea plantations. Tour was not overly informative. They were processing leaves at time of visit so it was nice to observe that and get some explanation. All be it rather short. They produce Orthodox (leaves remain somewhat in tact) and CTC (chopped leaves typically for tea bags) tea, the Orthodox production was a bit grey on detail. Nice cuppa afterwards. I would not go out of my way for this Tea factory, if you have been to Mackwoods, Bluefields or what I considered my best visit, Loolecondera Tea Factory then skip this.  Pedro did not make my top 5.
Really enjoyed this tour of the tea factory led by a very pleasant knowledgeable young lady. We saw the process from arrival of the leaves through to the final packing and got a taste at the end.

My wife and I been to the Pedro Tea Estate and we've enjoyed the tour inside the factory which seemed very organized. The tour guide was very informative and nice with kids. We highly recommend this factory than others  due it's view and nicely put tour.

For 200 rupees you can take a 30 minute tour around the factory, which is just enough time to see how everything works without getting bored ;-) Best visited in the afternoon when the leaves have been collected and are being processed.

For 200 rupees they offer a visit to the fabric and a cup of tea. The visit was very interesting, but we couldn't take any picture inside and the fabric wasn't working while the visit, so we couldn't see how machines work. Anyway, it's a very good visit to know how tea is produced. And in 30 minueltes you can arrive to Lover's Leap, a very beautiful waterfall nearby.

The tour we went on whilst very informative in the manufacture of tea spends no time on the plantation and the plants and the picking process. The tea at the end is nice and walkimg through the plantation makes for a good walk.

We were told that the tea processing is only at night so we were expecting to see only machines and stuff like that. However, we came at around 8am and we still saw some processes and how different kind of tea is being made and how does it look like. At the end of the tour we had some nice tea on a bench in the balcony of the tea shop where we could see a lovely view of tea plantations. We enjoyed that.
Love this place, we had a tour around the factory and saw the process of tea. afterwards had tea at the balcony, facing beautiful tea plantation. And view of nuwara Definitely Worth the visit.

This active tea factory can be visited to get a better inside on how tea is produced. There is busses going from and to nuwara eliya which stop right in front of the tea factory! The tour itself is about 30 minutes and after that you can have a cup of tea and wonder around the tea plantations! Beautiful scenery and entrance price is fair at 200rp!
We dropped in here for an early morning tour. Sadly they were just cleaning all the machinery up and the tour lacked some spark.

Very quick tour largely showing dormant machinery so not exactly the most stimulating time. It is patently a very old and established company and there should be some interesting history but it is not addressed at all

We visited the tea factory early morning and got on one of the first tours. The guide was very motivated and passionate. He had competent answers too all questions asked. The factory is very interesting, it is fascinating to see older machinery (up to 70 years) still running (economically) in our time. The factory is located between very well maintained tea plantations and is also a lovely place for a picnic. For us one of the highlights in Nuwara Eliya.

Pedro is a very clean and well organized tea factory. The entry fee is LKR-200/- They first offer a a cup of tea which is followed by a 30 minutes tour of the factory going through the entire process of tea making. Factory is only in operation in night so during day visits the machines are not working. Factory also offers some good quality tea and souvenirs to sell. Along the factory are the tea plantations. You can visit them as well free of cost. There are no pictures allowed during the tour inside the factory but you can take pictures in the tea fields.

Excellent colonial factory and tea centre  . Friendly  staff who explained  the tea making process  and kids loved it . The tea served was super and a place you must take  your kids to show the history  of Sri Lankan tea and  British influence .

Interesting tour of factory costing 200rs, but for this you get cup of tea and more importantly they don't try and sell you anything else! Afterwards head back to entrance, grab since snacks from vendors outside and take the track opposite in order to head up to lovers leap waterfall. Takes about 30 mins to walk up there, follow the well trodden path through plantations for some excellent views of nuwara eliya and the waterfall itself

We came here based on the recommendation in our Lonely Planet guide. When we arrived, nobody greeted us or explained where to go for a tour. We were then told to 'hurry up and buy a ticket' as people were waiting for us. It turned out that a tour had already started, and they just made us join that one mid way through, which was a bit poor. However, the tour that we did see was very informative and interesting and it was nice to see the machines in action. Do bear in mind that no photos are allowed inside the factory. At the end of the tour, we were given a free cup of tea overlooking the plantation. The surrounding area is beautiful and I understand that not all tea factory tours have these sort of views. The shop was disappointing, so we went to the Blue Field Tea Factory shop on our way home to pick up some nicely packaged tea for gifts. Overall, it was a good place to get an understanding of the tea making process and sit and have a nice cup of tea with a great view.

Went there on a Sunday with 3 friends. A lady guided us through the tea production process. However, the machinery was not functional which dampened the experience. I recommend going there on a fully functional day to get the best out of it. Its worth a trip.

If you are spending one day in Nuwara Eliya and you would like to visit a tea plantation, you should come here. The tour lasts approximately 20 minutes and the entrance is only 200 rupees. We had a nice tour guide who explained us how the tea is produced and showed us all the machineries replying to all our questions. They also offer a cup of tea at the end of the visit. After the tour we had a walk around the estate, where we could take really nice pictures (inside the factory it is forbidden) of the plantation.

Informative tour of quaint tea factory showing the process from picking to packaging and how the types of tea varieties are made. Had no idea that tea was processed so quickly and varieties all came from the same leaf.  Just seeing the ancient machinery still being used is worth the visit. Tour finishes with a cup of tea adjacent to the shop.

OK we went on a Sunday so no work was happening but it was still a good little tour and you get told what each bit of equipment/room does. NO PHOTOS so be warned! Some girl in the group on the same tour as us kept trying to take them sneekily and the lady had a go at her, they get their wages docked if people take photos so don't do it! Good tour and then you get to have 1 cup of Lover's Leap tea after in their little sitting area bit, look or buy some tea if you want or a cup or something. Quite dear though but I am drinking the tea now at home and it is nice!

Nice quick tour of the simple factory, lovely estate area for some nice photos or to relax with your cup of tea after the tour well worth the trip out of town. Should prob be combined with a walk to lovers leap waterfall which is nearby. (1-2km).

Arrived at 3pm. Only two in my party but there were at least 15 in total on the tour. Guide was very clear, smiley and professional. Process made clear. Both my mum and I big tea drinkers so very interesting. Not a long tour, about 35 minutes. More would probably be boring and excessive! They mainly process the tea at night due to temperature, but the machines not being on doesn't matter at all. It gives you a clear view of the factory. Tea served was surprisingly nice as I've had some poor quality tea in Sri Lanka (the good stuff is exported!). A nice trip for the cost (200lkr). Grounds are pretty and you can walk around afterwards (it was raining so we didn't). Note: we haggled a tuktuk for 500 to take us from the Kelegala area, where our hotel was, to Pedro, then to the grand hotel. He wanted 1000 but we stuck to our guns, even walked away when he wouldn't go down. I know some may get it cheaper, but just for an idea of cost

We arrived at 11am and the machines weren't working, however we were given a thorough tour of the tea factory costing 200r and lasting about 30 mins. Learnt much about how tea is picked, processed, manufactured and then graded and packed for sale and export all over the world. Both we and our teenage kids found it enjoyable and interesting. The tour ended up in the cafe overlooking the amazing estates, drinking a nice cup of BOPF- you'll know what this is after your visit !

I recommend the visit to Pedro Tea Estate, the tour and the explanation about the process is quite short, but after you can enjoy a cup of tea while watching the magnificent views from there. Also very recommendable the walk to the Lovers Leap, just 5 km away.
Nice visit with one cup of tea offered, you will have to buy extra cups to do the easing of the 6 different teas. Try to be there before 11am to see all the machines working.

A lovely place to visit and have some black tea. A factory is also available nearby which you can view. Note that they only sell black tea so if you want some of the more exquisite teas then I would recommend visiting some of the other tea fields in Nuwara Eliya. The best part of this tea estate is the view - and the fact that you can take a stroll in the tea fields - absolutely beautiful.
Expected a more detailed explanation of the production cycle (very quick and high lavel) and a tour within the plantation (not done)

At the Pedro Estate we were offered a tour in the tea-factory which was very  Interesting! There was a lot to learn about making all different kinds of tea. Also our teenage daughters loved this visit!
We visited on week day evening, they served us Hot Sri Lankan Tea with warm welcome for the factory tour. they gave us an whole idea about tea production. This is a must visit place in Nuwaraeliya.
We toured on Sunday so the factory was not operating but we still got a tour through and had explained to us how it all works. And a nice cup of tea at the end. Well worth it.
warm welcome and good explanation how tea is produced. The tea was tasted very good. Beautiful scenes and views. Large tea plantations.

Getting to one of the tea estate museums is well worthwhile - to learn something about the process of tea-making and why Ceylon tea is so famous.  Great to see the tea plantations from close-up and to learn about the 24 hour process with sorting, cutting, drying, grading, packing and tasting... Surprised to learn that what I thought were different teas such as Pekoe or English Breakfast are the same tea cut and graded to different sized leaves. More subtle and feint honey coloured, the better - although many prefer darker stronger tea.  What you won't learn about are worker conditions especially in the plantations and their homes - the lines - which have for centuries housed mostly Tamil labourer families. Fortunately some moves now being taken forward to improve conditions for these families and incorporate them more fully into Sri Lankan social and political life...

Unfortunately I arrived at this place on a national holiday so the factory was not operating. However, it was open for a guided tour which proved highly informative and gave me a good insight into the process that provides us with our daily 'cuppa' .  You get a free cup of tea at the end of the tour and the opportunity to purchase tea and related items, however I thought these were a bit overpriced.

Was given a very thorough and detailed tour of the factory by the very experienced staff. It was a wonderful tea making education that you can't get it anywhere. It is a must for anyone going up to the Nuwara Eliya region. The Lover Leap boutique is a nice touch. Don't miss the chance to have a go at picking tea leaves as well.

A nice tea factory to vissit. The sales women are eager to take you around and educate you on the process from picking of the tea leaves to drying and packaging and sampling. They have a store that sells you tea hampers

Interesting tour by a lady who was able to answer all our questions about how tea is made. Tea is such a big part of Sri Lanka's economy so good to understand it a bit more. Tour didn't take long - about twenty minutes with opportunities to try and buy some local tea. Walked up to Lovers Leap afterwards

It's all what we want to see when we are going there : - private visit of the factory (industrial -> so big volume) for 200 Rs - they explain the difference of black tea quality - you can go in the field - they offer you a cup of tea - you can buy tea souvenir
in nuwara eliya there are many tea gardens . this is one of them . walk around and click good shots to take back memories home .
There are many tea gardens in this area . So are the tea factories . They show you how tea is made . Than they make u taste tea . You can buy also.

Pedro's is a great place to start your tea plantation education. The factory is one of 16 in the Kalani Valey group and for 200 rupees each you get a guided tour through the entire factory, a tea afterwards and access to the plantation fields to wander about in. After the ladies pluck the young tea leaves (the men do other heavier work, apparently), they are delivered to the factory. The machines they use to dry, roll, grind, and grade the tea are more than 80 years old. Quite a miracle. You get full access to all areas of production - but no photos inside. Pedro says it's an ethical company - they don't use chemicals, give all 1300 employees housing and have funds for medical benefits and schooling for the children of the staff. We bought a mixed box of six teas there for 1700 rupee which you can only get at the plantation. The rest is sent to Colombo for auction. We got a tuk tuk to take us to Pedro then Macwoods for 1300 rupee from Nuwara Eliya. Highly recommended.
Very informative and enjoyable conducted factory tour first hand observation of the whole process from freshly plucked tea buds to final product packed and ready for the tea auction
This is a great tour - you get to see a lot even though the machines only work at night time as they make a light tea. Very informative - great value
It was a Sunday and the Factory was closed but yet we were explained the process which was very instructive and worth the entry fee.

The tea factory looks very 19th century. The tour cost 200 lkr and lasts about 15 minutes. The tea leaves arrive around noon, so before that you won't see any of the machines working. After noon the withering machine is supposed to work. The rest are only operational at night. Overall the tour was nice, but seeing working machines would be much better. The shop has a variety of expensive teas none of which are produced at the factory, since the factory doesn't do branding and packaging. The factory has a great view over the plantation.

Sri Lanka is famous for best tea in the world. You will be able to get good understanding of the tea making process from plucking the leaves to packaging. If machines are working then you will be able to see the whole process. You can select and buy processed tea starting from Rs. 250/- and each visitor is offered a fresh cup of tea. Mark this place a 'must go' in your places to visit in Nuwara Eliya.

The type of tea made here means that the whole process takes less than 24 hours - the withered leaves aren't fermented.  Much of the processing is undertaken out of tourist opening hours.  The brief tour is functional, but lacks the experience that comes from visiting a tea factory with all the machinery functioning, the heat and the smells.  The first fresh leaves do not arrive until late morning, so best to avoid a visit before noon as even the dryers are empty and switched off.  We were given a very clear instruction not to take photos, although it was unclear why.  It is worth considering other tea factories for a fuller experience, but if this is your only chance to see a tea factory, then you will get an idea of how tea leaves are prepared for market.

we enjoyed our visit to the tea factory. the staff work through the night so it was very quiet. We saw a few machines drying some of the tea leaves, and the rest were stationary. It was very interesting to see and hear how tea is made. You can buy from the little shop too - I think its a little expensive, but the boxes make nice gifts. Tuk Tuk drivers try to rip you off.. we paid 400 rupees (2 GBP), to go there and back from the city centre with him waiting. The tour takes about 10 minutes and costs 200 rupees (1GBP). You can walk through tea fields also.

The day we visited their machines were not working. They will still walk you through the manual process with a guide though no fun without looking at the entire process. They charge you LKR 200 per person which is pretty reasonable and includes a cup of tea. Even if you don't take the tour, you can have the tea for LKR 50. Best area to drink tea is to sit at the gallery.
Oldest black tea factory in Sri Lanka. Good access and car park. Very nice view of tea farms. A very kind guide who show us all the factory and a great taste of sample tea... Must see

I found the tour of this tea factory very interesting and informative but the tour guide was quite rude and she fed us a sob story before the tour of how the workers are underpaid etc (clearly looking for tips). Afterwards you get a cup of tea and can buy tea from the shop at a pretty reasonable price, but the selection is small. There was no work going on the day we arrived because it was full moon day but this did not really detract from the tour. The estate has lovely views and i would recommend walking or taking a tuktuk to lovers leap waterfall nearby.
We had a 30 minute tour, which was perfect. It was very interesting, shame we couldn't take photos inside the factory...but a good tour none the less.

It was fascinating to walk round the factory watching the production of 8 grades of tea and it's all done by hand with old fashioned machinery and not a computer in sight ! The final product is sold at auction to the big companies like Brooke Bond and Lipton who re-brand the tea and probably make a lot more money than the tea plantation and factory.  It's lovely seeing the ladies out plucking the tea - a splash of colour in a sea of green.

We visited the Pedro factory after visiting Lover's Leap falls across the road. The tea they served us was over-brewed and bitter (even though it was their lighter tea). We paid for their factory tour which was a lot better than the one we went through at Mackwoods Labookellie tea centre. This tour was for over 30 mins and covered all processes of tea making, took us deep into the factory and showed us most of their machinery. Visit if you are interested in the tea process. Also, they don't sell a big variety of tea (unlike Mackwoods which has a huge collection) and most of their offerings are packets of 6 or so, hence you can't really pick and choose different varieties of tea.

Slightly disappointing as the machinery was not working. we only had a guide, who was very good, but you did not get the feel of the produce being processed, felt all they wanted was you to spend money

This factory is the closest one from Nuwara Eliya, but its maybe the worst one, as it has sooo much publicity in all guide boooks and gets more touristy than the others. It is the only one that asks for entrance ticket (100), and offers same service - tour & cup of tea.

While in tea country we visited Mackwoods and Pedros and enjoyed Pedros far more. We we taken into the production areas and saw everything up close and had an excellent guide who explained everything really well. Must admit the tea wasn't as good as Mackwoods though
Really a Great Location With an Amazing view of the "Lovers Leap" Water fall. Surrounded by the Pedro Range Nuwara Eliya. Nearly 8km from the city center towards the Udapussallawa Road. 15mins Drive

Having spent time in the area of tea plantations we were keen to see how tea was produced, our guide recommended Pedros to us, the factory tour covers the whole process from plant to finish product in great detail get to see all the processes at work. At the end you can sample the tea and wonder through some of the plantation, beautiful views.

We stopped here as this tea plantation is located across the road going up to the Lover's Leap falls. It can be easily and cheaply reached by taking the bus to Borlander. The grounds are not as nice as the ones at Mackwoods Labookelie. We did not do the tour as we have already done the one at Mackwoods Labookelie. They charge 200 rupees for the tour here. When we were leaving, we were lucky to see a large group of tea pickers returning to the plantation with their tea leaves baskets.

A few Kms outside the town. Our driver arranged a private guide to show us the production area which was fascinating and wonderful to be able to view the processes really up close. After a free cup of tea we were able to wander through the tea plantation which was so enjoyable. We happily bought a couple of packs of tea that has been produced on site. Very friendly people.

We enjoyed our one hour visit to the tea factory. The young lady showing us what went on was delightful, although at times it was difficult to hear what she was saying because of the machinery noise. The view from the factory is spectacular. Well worth the time spent.

We enjoyed the tea, we loved seeing the tea factory and bought gifts of superb tea for all at home. The estate GM was in at the time, frankly it was hard to believe that someone with so many staff could be welcoming and have so much time to chat. Big thanks! We will be back!
An interesting tour, a great explanation of the process. Make sure you take the time to stroll through the tea fields themselves.
Insightful and interesting, quite well priced. Be sure to stroll through the tea plantations themselves.

My idea of a factory is to see the process from the bush to my cup. I wanted to see what the tea looks like at every stage, and because they don't work during the day, you can't see this. Even a jar of what the tea would look like would have been helpful. Why you had to wear an apron was beyond me. We then got our guide to take us to a working factory. We wished we had gone straight to that one.

Four of us were taken here by our tour driver as an extra due to the rain. Glad we did as tour was very interesting with a sample cup of tea and the end. Nice friendly staff with good explanations of what was going on.
